trustees ____________ michael m lorge corporate counsel ____________ john t lockerby manager preface this a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the village of skokie illinois source materials used in the preparation of the the 1979 as supplemented ordinances subsequently adopted by the mayor and board of trustees the source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof by use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this the reader can locate any section of the 1979 as supplemented and any subsequent ordinance included herein the chapters of the been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage notes which tie related sections of the which refer to relevant state law have been included a table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the included at the back of this system the chapter and section numbering system used in this the same system used in many state and local government codes each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash the figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter thus the second section of is numbered 12 and the first section of is 61 under this system each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments for example if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between is desired to be added such new section would be numbered 615 new articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or in the case of articles may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and in the case of divisions may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject the next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division new chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters page numbering system the page numbering system used in this a prefix system the letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume the number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion in the case of a chapter of the the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter the following are typical parts of codes of ordinances which may or may not appear in this this time and their corresponding prefixes code cd code comparative tables cct1 state law reference table slt1 code index cdi1 index the index has been prepared with the greatest of care each particular item has been placed under several headings some of which are couched in lay phraseology others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees there are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested looseleaf supplements a special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication with this system the publication will be kept uptodate subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the affected page or pages will be reprinted these new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages keeping this publication uptodate at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication as revised pages are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions it is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and in addition that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes acknowledgments this publication was under the direct supervision of bill carroll senior connie timmons editor of the municipal tallahassee florida credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publishers staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project the publisher is most grateful to barbara meyer corporation counsel mark vanderpool assistant village manager keith glatz purchasing agent and marlene williams village clerk for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication it is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a ordinances which will make the active law of the village readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the daytoday village of skokie illinois 2002 adopting ordinance ordinance no 024c3077 an amending enacting codifying and consolidating the general ordinances of the village of skokie illinois providing for the repeal of ordinances not included therein with certain exceptions and for other purposes whereas the village of skokie is an illinois home rule municipality pursuant to of the illinois constitution 1970  and whereas on  the mayor and board of trustees of the village of skokie adopted the recodification of the ordinances for the village of skokie skokie village   and whereas the corporation counsel and village manger recommended to the mayor and board of trustees at a public meeting duly held that the village updated and that the mayor and board of trustees adopt the recodification of the ordinances  and whereas the mayor and board of trustees concurred in the aforesaid recommendation  now therefore be it ordained by the mayor and board of trustees of the village of skokie cook county illinois for the purposes of revising amending enacting codifying and consolidating the general ordinances and laws of the village of skokie illinois and pursuant to the home rule powers granted to the village of skokie under the constitution and laws of the state of illinois the following chapters to wit chapters 1 inclusive attached hereto and incorporated by reference as if set forth verbatim herein are hereby adopted and passed as and for the general ordinances of the village of skokie illinois and shall constitute and be known as the skokie village  the provisions of the skokie village shall take effect and be in force upon the passage approval and publication in pamphlet form by the village clerk as required by law the provisions appearing in the skokie village insofar as they are substantially the same as those of the skokie village regardless of their location and numbering and those of all other ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of said skokie village shall be construed as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments provisions of the skokie village as amended including  not set forth in the same or substantially the same form in the skokie village except as hereafter provided shall be deemed repealed by this ordinance amending the skokie village adopted on or after  shall be deemed to amend the skokie village  where an ordinance adopted on or after  amended any portion of the skokie village which was renumbered or relocated so as to be retained and included as a successor provision of the skokie village said ordinance shall be deemed to have amended the successor provision of the skokie village wherever located the repeal provided for in of this not be deemed to repeal any ordinance not amending or having been codified into the skokie village  the repeal provided for in of this not be deemed to repeal the zoning regulations as contained in the skokie village as has been amended from time to time the repeal provided for in of this not be deemed to affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty forfeiture or punishment incurred or any claim contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this   nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the village or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the village or any evidence of the villages indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the village  nor shall said repeal affect the administrative ordinances and resolutions of the village not in conflict or inconsistent with the skokie village   nor shall said repeal affect any annual appropriation ordinance of the village any ordinance or resolution concerning levying or imposing any tax or imposing any fee other than that set forth specifically in the skokie village   nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution relating to wages salaries and bonds of any village officer or employee  nor shall said repeal affect any right or franchise conferred by ordinance or resolution of the village on any person or entity  nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution concerning or relating to the annexation or to extending or reducing the boundaries of the village  nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution establishing the grades of streets and avenues and the several railroad tracks in the village  nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution establishing naming or vacating any street alley or other place or assuming jurisdiction over same  nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution relating to or granting powers to other governmental entities or relating in any way to the construction operation and maintenance of the villages water supply or sewer system or any other municipal utility  nor shall said repeal affect any ordinance or resolution concerning the transfer of prisoners to places of accommodation elections zoning ordinances or variations or special uses granted pursuant thereto the transfer acceptance lease sale or purchase of any real or personal property or any ordinance or resolution concerning special assessments or special taxing districts  nor shall said repeal affect any prosecution suit or other proceeding pending or any judgment rendered prior to the effective date of this  that this be in full force and effect from and after its passage approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by law adopted this 15th day of april 2002 ayes 7 piper bromberg such particular acts outside the corporate limits 05 penalties a standard penalty 1 whenever in this in any ordinance or in any rule or regulation of the village any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or an offense or whenever in this any ordinance or any rule or regulation the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful where no specific penalty is provided therefor any person upon the violation of any ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $75000 for each and every subsequent day until such time as it is abated corrected or no longer exists the corporation counsel may file a civil action to recover any penalty or fine as imposed by an administrative law officer judge or any appropriate entity or tribunal so authorized against any such person  provided however that the filing of such civil action shall preclude incarceration or imprisonment 2 in addition to any other fine or penalty provided for by this section or any other section of this the court may also impose as a sentence any one of the following a an amount of restitution to any person or entity suffering personal injury or property damage as the result of the conduct  b a period of community service  c mandatory attendance at remedial counseling treatment or educational sessions b revocation or suspension the revocation or suspension of a license registration or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any penalty being enforced c establishment of escrow accounts the village managers designee with the approval of the village manager or corporation counsel is authorized to establish escrow accounts to assist the village in resolving disputes relating to 1 the issuance of a permit license or certificate of occupancy  or 2 conditions relating to a plan commission or zoning board of appeals case the terms of the escrow account shall be determined by the village manager the village managers designee or the corporation counsel d violations 1 each act of violation and each subsequent day the violation continues shall elicit a fine not to exceed $75000 until such time as the violation no longer exists 2 there shall be a presumption of a continuing violation until adjudicated or until the village manager or designee determines that the violation has been abated corrected or no longer exists 3 daily fines for the violation shall accrue for the duration of time as outlined in d2 4 the imposition of the accruing fine or any part thereof shall be at the discretion of the administrative law officer or judge e notice upon service of a citation for any violation of this it shall be sufficient to provide notice of continuing daily fines if no compliance has been achieved by mail to the last known arrowhead containing the profile of an indian with a chiefs headdress this symbolizes the original inhabitants of the area below the indian head there shall be the number  arranged vertically which shall indicate the date of incorporation of the municipality 26 datum for levels and grades a the base line or datum for the village levels and grades is hereby established as measured from the plane duties of any office or position or in the issuance of a license or permit or for the exercise of special privilege the surety on such bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do business in this state as a surety company in the absence of specific provision to the contrary by ordinance whenever in its opinion additional sureties or an additional surety may be needed on any bond to indemnify the village against any loss or liability because of the insolvency of the existing surety or sureties or for any other reason the mayor and board of trustees may order a new surety or sureties to be secured on such bond if such new surety or sureties are not procured within 10 days from the time such order is transmitted to the principal on the bond or the principals assignee the board of trustees shall declare the bond to be void and thereupon such principal or assignee shall be deemed to have surrendered the privilege or position as a condition of which the bond was  functions the board of trustees shall consist of the mayor and 6 trustees the trustees shall be elected by the electors of the village to office for 4year terms as is provided by statute the mayor the board of trustees shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute 02 compensation of members the members of the board of trustees shall receive such annual compensation as is fixed by the disability conviction of a disqualifying crime abandonment of office or removal from office or by removal of residence from the village b if a vacancy in the office of a trustee occurs during the term to january 1 of each year meetings shall be called to order at  pm if such meeting date should fall on a holiday or if there is no quorum present the meeting shall be held at the same hour on the next business day or as determined by the mayor and board of trustees the board of trustees may temporarily hold its meetings in any other convenient place upon giving at least 24 hours public notice 04 state law reference meetings 65 ilcs 5314025 applicability of open meetings act all meetings of the mayor and board of trustees shall be held in accordance with the illinois open meetings act 5 ilcs 1201 et seq a a verbatim record of all closed meetings in the form of an audio record shall be made by the village clerk or designee a statement shall be made at the beginning of each recording identifying the participants and the purpose of the closed meeting all verbatim records of closed meetings are hereby declared confidential and are not subject to release except as required by e of the illinois open meetings act the village clerk shall maintain the verbatim record for a minimum of eighteen months from the date of the closed meeting each verbatim record shall be labeled with the date time and place of the meeting b the village clerk shall create written minutes of all closed meetings the minutes shall include i exemption applicable to the closed meeting  ii the date time and place of the meeting  iii the elected officials that are present and those that are absent  iv the identity of other persons present  v a summary of discussion  and vi a record of any vote taken the approved minutes are deemed to be the official record of the minutes and verbatim record shall not be part of the official record of any meeting c unless otherwise required by law or ordered by a court no person shall have access to any verbatim record the prohibition on the review of a verbatim record does not apply to the village clerk village manager or corporation counsel who may review a verbatim record if they deem it necessary in the event the village clerk village manager or corporation counsel deem it necessary to review a verbatim record that person shall notify the other two persons in writing a review of a verbatim record shall only take place in the office of the village clerk and in the presence of two or more of the aforesaid individuals the village clerk shall maintain a log indicating date time and persons present of any review made of verbatim records notwithstanding any other provision none of the three aforementioned individuals shall have the authority to review a verbatim record wherein they are the subject of the meeting d on a regular basis the village clerk shall send a written notice to the mayor trustees village manager and the corporation counsel listing all verbatim records scheduled for destruction the notice shall include a synopsis of the subject of the closed session for which the verbatim record was created the village manager and corporation counsel shall jointly determine whether it is necessary to preserve a verbatim record for the purposes contemplated by e of the illinois open meetings act and shall so instruct the village clerk if their determination is that the record needs to be preserved or that it may be erased or destroyed e the mayor and board of trustees shall semiannually at the second meeting in january and the second meeting in june consider the status of written minutes and verbatim records of executive sessions held by the mayor and the board of trustees in accordance with the illinois open meetings act 05  c3251  1 2172004 notice of meetings a whenever required notice shall be either given by mail deposited in a us mail receptacle or post office or deliveries by messenger or may be given to board of trustees members at a prior regular or special meeting and noted in the recorded minutes notice may be waived in writing at any time and the attendance of a board of trustees member at a special meeting or the members voting on any issue shall constitute a waiver of notice as to such issue without any written waiver b where written notice is required notice shall be mailed or delivered to the last known address of the board of trustees member by regular mail and deposited in a us mail receptacle or post office not less than 48 hours prior to the time set for the call to order of the meeting 06 state law reference special meetings call notices 65 ilcs 5314025 quorum and majority vote a a quorum of the mayor and board of trustees shall consist of a majority of the entire board of trustees any 4 of the 7 members of the board of trustees shall constitute a quorum a quorum shall be necessary to transact the business of the board of trustees members of the board of trustees shall only be considered in attendance at a meeting if such member is physically present attendance by electronic means at a meeting of the board of trustees is hereby prohibited b a majority vote of the board of trustees unless otherwise stated shall consist of not less than 4 members a majority vote shall be required to adopt any ordinance or resolution or take affirmative action on any motion the nature of which is other than procedural 07 state law reference quorum of corporate authorities 65 ilcs 5314020  vote required 65 ilcs 5314040 presiding officer the mayor shall preside at all meetings of the board of trustees the mayor shall vote on any ordinance resolution or motion an acting mayor or a mayor pro tempore shall vote in such persons capacity as a trustee but shall not be entitled to another vote in such persons capacity as acting mayor or mayor pro tempore the mayor or mayor pro tempore shall announce the result of the board of trustees vote 08 state law reference presiding officer at meetings 65 ilcs 5314030 veto powers of mayor all resolutions and motions i which create any liability against the village or ii which provide for the expenditure of appropriation of its money or iii to sell any village property and all ordinances passed by the board of trustees shall be deposited with the village clerk if the mayor approves of them the mayor shall sign them if the mayor disapproves of any the mayor shall return them to the board of trustees with the mayors written objections at the next regular meeting of the board of trustees the mayor may disapprove of any 1 or more sums appropriated in any ordinance resolution or motion making an appropriation or the mayor may disapprove entirely of an ordinance resolution or motion making an appropriation if the mayor fails to return any ordinance or any specified resolution or motion with the mayors written objections within the designated time it shall become effective despite the absence of the mayors signature 09 state law reference veto power 65 ilcs 5314045 passage over veto every resolution and motion specified in every ordinance which is returned to the board of trustees by the mayor shall be reconsidered by the board of trustees if after such reconsideration 23 of all the trustees elected to the board of trustees shall vote to pass an ordinance resolution or motion notwithstanding the mayors refusal to approve it then it shall be effective the vote on a question of passage over the mayors veto shall be by yeas and nays and shall be recorded in the minutes 10 state law reference similar provisions 65 ilcs 5314050 meetings to be open to public all meetings of the mayor and board of trustees shall be open to the public except as provided by ordinance or statute 11 state law reference rules of expulsion 65 ilcs 5314015 rules of order the current edition of roberts rules of order shall govern the proceedings of the board of trustees except where in conflict with the following rules rule 1 the agenda for a regular or special meeting shall be prepared by the manager the manager or designee shall cause a copy of the agenda to be posted on the last business day prior to the meeting date trustees the corporation counsel or department heads desiring matters to be placed on the agenda shall so notify the manager within time sufficient for the manager to prepare the agenda and distribute copies to mayor and board of trustees each trustee or department head shall also designate any matters which are to be placed on the consent agenda the consent agenda contains all routine matters which do not require further discussion all items on the consent agenda are to be marked with an asterisk on the regular agenda before the vote is taken any item will be dropped from the consent agenda at the request of the mayor a trustee or any person in attendance at the meeting that item will then be taken up at its regular place on the printed agenda the mayor shall take the chair at the hour at which the meeting shall have been called the board of trustees shall take up business in the following order a pledge of allegiance b call meeting to order and roll call c approve consent agenda d approve minutes of last meeting e approve voucher list f proclamations g recognitions presentations and awards h appointments reappointments and resignations i report of the village manager j report of the corporation counsel k unfinished business l new business m plan commission cases n miscellaneous o citizens comments p adjournment rule 2 the mayor shall preserve order and decorum and may speak upon and decide all questions of order rule 3 the mayor may call upon any member of the board of trustees to temporarily perform the duties of the chair but such substitution shall not extend beyond an adjournment rule 4 every question or motion when seconded shall be stated by the mayor before it is open for debate when a question is put the vote shall be conducted by a roll call vote the village clerk shall enter the words omnibus vote in the journal in lieu of entering the names of the members of the board of trustees and each of their votes for all items which are on the consent agenda rule 5 all board of trustees committees shall consist of 3 members of which the mayor may be 1 and such committees shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the trustees rule 6 every member previous to speaking shall address the presiding officer as mr mayor but shall not proceed with the members remarks until named and recognized by the chair rule 7 if any member disregards the rule of the board of trustees the mayor or any member may call the member to order and when called to order the member shall take the members seat unless permitted to explain rule 8 every member when a question is taken shall vote unless excused by the board of trustees or if the member is directly interested in the question in which case the member shall abstain from voting rule 9 after a resolution or a motion is stated by the mayor it shall be deemed to be in the possession of the board of trustees but it may be withdrawn by the maker thereof with the consent of the trustee seconding prior to the call for the vote by the mayor rule 10 when a motion is in the possession of the board of trustees no other motion shall be received except as specified in this rule which shall have precedence in the order stated as follows a to fix the time to adjourn b to adjourn c to take a recess d to raise a question of privilege e to call for the orders of the day f to lay on the table g to call for the previous question h to limit or extend limits of debates i to postpone to a certain time j to commit or refer k to amend l to postpone indefinitely m to call the main motion rule 11 the motion to adjourn or lay on the table shall be decided without debate and the motion to fix the time to which to adjourn and the motion to adjourn shall always be in order except a when a member is in possession of the floor b while the members are voting c while the vote is being verified d when it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken e when adjournment was the last preceding motion rule 12 all votes shall be by roll call rule 13 an amendment to a motion does not require a separate vote on the amendment if the movants of the original motion concur with the amendment rule 14 when a trustee calls for the question it signifies a request of the chair to close debate and to vote on the pending motion rule 15 no vote shall be called for on an ordinance at the same meeting at which it shall be first introduced unless there first be a unanimous vote of the members present to suspend the rules  providing that no less than 5 members of the board of trustees are present and voting on the motion to suspend the rules this rule shall not apply to any ordinance the subject matter of which was the subject matter of a recommendation of a commission board committee or staff member charged with the making of a recommendation to the board of trustees at a regular meeting every ordinance when first introduced shall have its title read the contents explained and the date it will next be considered announced rule 16 a vote may be called for on all resolutions at the same meeting at which the resolution is first introduced resolutions of a routine nature may be placed on the consent agenda rule 17 all ordinances before passage shall be approved as to form by the corporation counsel of the village rule 18 for purposes of identification all ordinances shall be numbered consecutively and shall be further identified by using the last 2 digits of the year in which the ordinance is passed followed by a hyphen followed by a numeral designating the month in which it is passed such ordinances may be further identified by a classification system based upon the subject matter rule 19 for purposes of identification all resolutions shall be numbered consecutively and shall be further identified by using the last 2 digits of the year in which the resolution is passed followed by a hyphen followed by an r such resolutions may be further identified by a classification system based upon the subject matter rule 20 the village clerk shall cause to be published in pamphlet form or by publication those ordinances which the statutes of the state require to be published within the limit prescribed by statute rule 21 special committees of trustees or of citizens may be appointed at any time by the mayor with the advice and consent of the trustees to consider any special problems or issues of concern rule 22 all standing and special committees to which any matter may be referred shall report thereon in writing at a designated regular meeting giving the facts and their opinion thereon and the report shall be signed by a majority of the committee rule 23 when a question before the board of trustees contains several propositions any member may call for a division of the question so as to take a vote on each proposition separately rule 24 all petitions addressed to the board of trustees shall be in writing and filed with the village clerk who shall present the petitions to the board of trustees except as otherwise provided by statute rule 25 all resolutions proclamations and ordinances adopted by the board of trustees shall be filed and preserved by the village clerk rule 26 in all cases when a resolution or motion shall be entered in the minutes of the board of trustees the name of the member moving the name of the member seconding and the exact vote shall also be entered in the minutes rule 27 copies of all reports proposed ordinances and resolutions shall wherever possible be made available to all members of the board of trustees rule 28 no contract to which the village is a party shall be considered as having been entered into unless it is in writing and has been approved by the board of trustees at a public meeting rule 29 any person or delegation may be recognized by the mayor to speak on any matter under discussion each speaker should come forward give the speakers identity and state the speakers address unless otherwise specified by the board of trustees a speakers presentation shall be limited to 5 minutes rule 30 plan commission recommendations shall be considered within 120 days after the close of the plan commission hearing on a case the board of trustees shall perform one of the following acts a concur with the recommendation  b reject the recommendation  c table further consideration to a date certain or until such time as further information may be received  or d refer the matter back to the plan commission for further study or hearing if the board of trustees fails to take any action within 6 months it shall be considered a denial of the plan commissions recommendation a majority vote shall be required to concur with any recommendation of the plan commission a majority vote of the members present shall be sufficient to table or to refer back if a required vote cannot be had because of the absence of any 1 or more members of the board of trustees the matter shall be tabled to the next regular meeting at which the required attendance may be had where the recommendation of the plan commission is to deny a petition and the recommendation has not been concurred with by the board of trustees as required by this rule the next question immediately presented to the board of trustees shall be the affirmative motion to pass upon the petition as required a favorable majority vote shall be required to adopt the motion the corporation counsel shall prepare and present to the board of trustees an ordinance where required to effect the action of the board of trustees as soon after the consideration of the matter by the board of trustees as possible no ordinance shall be adopted except by affirmative vote as stated in this section rule 31 any member acting or appearing in a disgraceful manner or who uses violent obscene or insulting language to or about the mayor andor any member of the board of trustees or who does not obey the order of the chair shall be on motion censured by a majority vote of the members present or expelled from the meeting by a 23 vote of all the elected members rule 32 all new business introduced at any meeting shall be referred to the appropriate committee or the village manager or lie over until the next meeting rule 33 any or all of the preceding rules may be temporarily suspended by the unanimous vote of all the board of trustees members present or may be amended by the majority vote of the board of trustees rule 34 the village manager shall determine bid reports which are of a routine nature and shall have them placed on the managers report as consent agenda items rule 35 a motion to reconsider can only be made at the regularly scheduled meeting following the meeting at which the vote to be considered was taken the motion to reconsider must be made by a member who voted with the prevailing side 13  c3735  1 212010 emergency interim successor for vacancies mayor clerk and trustee a purpose the purpose of this to ensure a functioning government during or as a result of a disaster as defined herein by ensuring that there is a procedure to fill vacancies in the offices of the mayor clerk or trustee a vacancy that is permanent shall always be filled on a permanent basis if there is a quorum of the mayor and the board of trustees b definitions for purposes of this the following words or phrases are defined as follows 1 unavailable means either that a vacancy in office exists or that the lawful incumbent of the office is unable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office 2 emergency interim successor means a person designated pursuant to this in the event the officer is unavailable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of an office or until a successor is appointed or elected and qualified as may be provided by the constitution statutes charters and ordinances or until the lawful incumbent is able to resume the exercise of the powers and discharge of the duties 3 disaster means a situation in which an occurrence or threat of catastrophic and widespread injury or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or manmade cause including but not limited to fire flood earthquake epidemic and explosion a disaster occurs when the governor declares that a disaster exists or for a local disaster when the village manager or mayor and board of trustees declares that a disaster exists c determination of vacancy in the event that any of the offices of mayor clerk or trustees becomes vacant then those persons remaining in the offices of mayor and trustees shall declare the office vacant the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with of the illinois municipal with of the skokie village d determination of vacancy in a disaster in the event that the person duly serving as mayor clerk or trustees becomes unavailable during or as a result of a disaster then those persons remaining as mayor and trustees shall declare the office vacant and shall determine whether such vacancy is permanent or temporary 1 if the vacancy is permanent and a quorum of the mayor and trustees may be achieved then the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with of the illinois municipal the of the skokie village 2 if the vacancy is determined to be permanent and a quorum of the mayor and trustees can not be achieved then the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with paragraph e of this 3 if the vacancy is determined to be temporary then the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with paragraph f of this determination of whether the vacancy is temporary shall be based upon the reasonable expectation of the unavailable officer resuming his or her powers and duties within ninety days e permanent vacancy in the event a permanent vacancy occurs in any of the offices of mayor clerk or trustee during or as the result of a disaster and a quorum of the mayor and board of trustees is not possible then one or more emergency interim successors shall automatically succeed to the office of trustee until there are a sufficient number of the mayor if available and trustees including emergency interim successors serving as trustees to achieve a quorum upon achieving a quorum the mayor and board of trustees shall fill any and all permanent vacancies including any vacancy for which an emergency interim successor is serving in accordance with of the illinois municipal of the skokie village f temporary vacancy in the event a temporary vacancy occurs in the office mayor or clerk during or as a result of a disaster then the board of trustees shall designate one of its remaining members as emergency interim mayor or clerk as the case may be in the event a temporary vacancy occurs in the office of trustees then one or more emergency interim successors shall automatically succeed to the office of trustee on a temporary basis an emergency interim successor shall serve as a temporary designee of the office until such time as the person for which an emergency interim successor had been named is available to continue in the performance of official duties then the duly elected person shall resume his or her prior office and the emergency interim successor shall resume serving in the capacity held prior to her or his designation as an emergency interim successor in the event the office of mayor clerk or trustees is declared to be temporarily vacant during or as a result of a disaster and the vacancy continues for ninety days or more then the office shall be declared to be permanently vacant and the vacancy shall be filled consistent with the procedures established in subparagraph e above g order of succession in the event of a disaster and it becomes necessary for an emergency interim successor to serve in the capacity of mayor clerk or trustees then the person appointed to the following named positions shall serve as an emergency interim successors in the order of succession listed below 1 chairman of the plan commission  2 chairman of the police and fire commission  3 chairman of the zoning board of appeals  4 chairman of the appearance commission  5 vice chairman of the plan commission  6 vice chairman of the police and fire commission  7 vice chairman of the zoning board of appeals  8 vice chairman of the appearance commission  and should it be necessary to continue the order of succession the next person designated would be the member with the most seniority on the plan commission and if exhausted then the next person designated is the member with the highest seniority on police and fire commission zoning board of appeals and appearance commission respectively emergency interim trustees shall be designated until the number of trustees and emergency interim successors serving as trustees is sufficient to constitute a quorum h special election in the event an emergency interim successor is performing the duties of mayor clerk or trustees due to a permanent vacancy and such person is performing the duties prior to the date specified in of the illinois municipal ilcs 5311050 2002 which would require a special election to fill the unexpired portion of the term then the special election shall be conducted in accordance with the illinois election c3377  1 812005 secs 246260  reserved article iii  officers and employees footnotes  3  cross reference ordinances village officers 65 ilcs 531255 et seq indemnification a it is found and declared by the mayor and board of trustees of the village as follows 1 the village has the power to indemnify its officials both elected and appointed and employees pursuant to law and the constitution of the state 2 it is in the best interests of the village to provide for the indemnification of its officials both elected and appointed and employees against claims expenses and liabilities such persons may be subject to by reason of those persons acting in their capacity as officials both elected and appointed or employees of the village b the village shall indemnify any person who was or is a party or is threatened to be made a party to any threatened pending or completed claim action suit or proceeding whether civil administrative or investigative by reason of any act or omission error misstatement or misleading statement or neglect or breach of duty which could reasonably be construed to have been committed attempted or allegedly committed or attempted by such person a wrongful act in the discharge of such persons duties in the persons capacity as an official either elected or appointed or employee of the village against expenses including attorneys fees judgments and amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by the person in connection with such action suit or proceeding if such person acted in good faith and in a manner which the person reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interests of the village this indemnification shall not apply to any claim suit action or proceeding 1 which is for the return by any such official either elected or appointed or employee of any remuneration paid in fact to such person without the previous approval of the village if it shall be determined by a judgment or other final adjudication that such remuneration is in violation of law or if such remuneration is to be repaid to the village under a settlement agreement  2 which is for an accounting of profits made from the purchase or sale by such official either elected or appointed or employee of securities of the village under any federal or state law  3 which is brought about or contributed to by the fraudulent or dishonest acts of such official either elected or appointed or employee if a judgment or other final adjudication adverse to such official either elected or appointed or employee establishes that acts of active and deliberate dishonesty were committed or attempted by such official either elected or appointed or employee with actual dishonest purpose and intent and were material to the cause of action so adjudicated  4 which is brought about or contributed to by any criminal activities of such official either elected or appointed or employee except in the case of such official either elected or appointed in respect of a wrongful act taken by a majority of the board of trustees or in the case of such official either elected or appointed or employee specifically directed by such a majority  5 which is based upon or attributable to such official either elected or appointed or employee having gained any personal profit or advantage to which such person was not legally entitled whether or not i a judgment or other final adjudication adverse to such person establishes that such a person in fact gained personal profit or other advantage to which the person was not entitled or ii the official either elected or appointed or employee has entered into a settlement agreement to repay such personal profit or advantage to the village  6 for which the village is not authorized by law to provide indemnification to the official either elected or appointed or employee  7 brought by the village at the direction of its board of trustees against an official either elected or appointed or employee  or 8 brought against any fire or police pension board member for any acts arising from or in the course of the members duties as a pension board member due to the independent nature of such boards c the village shall indemnify only those officials both elected and appointed or employees of the village from whom or with respect to whom the village has received written notice of a wrongful act to the extent practicable any notice from such official either elected or appointed or employee shall be mailed as soon as practicable and shall identify the official either elected or appointed or employee seeking indemnification and contain information with respect to the time place and circumstances of the wrongful act the names and addresses of any injured persons and the names of any available witnesses in the case where legal proceedings have commenced indemnification may be denied if the official either elected or appointed or employee has failed to mail to the village within 10 days after receiving service of process a copy of such process relating to a wrongful act unless i the village has otherwise received a copy of or written notice of such process or ii the failure to notify within such 10day period does not adversely impact upon the villages ability to defend such claim d the village shall indemnify the official either elected or appointed or employee for any damages expenses court costs and legal fees incurred in connection with any settlement of a claim action or proceeding where such settlement has been approved in advance by the village e any indemnification under subsection b of this section unless ordered by a court shall be made by the village only upon a determination that indemnification of the person is required by this section such determination shall be made 1 by the mayor and board of trustees by a majority vote of a quorum of the board of trustees who were not parties to such claim suit action or proceeding  2 if such quorum is not obtainable or even if obtainable and a quorum of disinterested board of trustees members by independent legal counsel in a written opinion  or 3 by a court of appropriate jurisdiction f expenses incurred by any person who may have a right of indemnification pursuant to this section in defending a civil claim suit action or proceeding shall be paid by the village in advance of the final disposition of such claim suit action or proceeding as authorized by the board of trustees upon receipt of an undertaking by or on behalf of such person to repay such amount to the village unless it shall ultimately be determined that such person is entitled to be indemnified by the village pursuant to this section g any official either elected or appointed or employee against whom any action suit or proceeding is brought may employ the officials or employees own attorney provided that such attorney is reasonably acceptable to the village and provided further that the costs of such attorney shall not be paid by the village unless the corporation counsels office or unless independent counsel for the suit or proceeding h the indemnification provided under this section shall be in addition to and not exclusive of any other indemnity or insurance to which the indemnitee may be entitled and such footnotes  4  state law reference functions and duties of mayor 65 ilcs 531355 et seq election  term a village mayor shall be elected by the electors of the village at a general municipal election for a term of 4 years in the year of 1977 and every 4th year thereafter such person shall be mayor of the board of trustees and such person shall hold such office until the persons successor is elected and is duly qualified such person shall be referred to as mayor of the village of skokie  powers and duties the mayor shall be the official head of the village for all legal purposes the mayor shall at all times have the power and authority to examine and inspect all books and records relating to village business kept by any village agent employee or officer the mayor shall sign all proclamations commissions resolutions and ordinances issued or adopted by the board of trustees except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance  vacancies  acting mayor a a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor by reason of resignation failure of a mayor to be elected or to qualify death permanent physical or mental disability conviction of a disqualifying crime abandonment of office or removal from office or by removal of the mayors residence from the village b if a vacancy occurs in the office of the mayor during the mayors term the vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of the term at the next election of trustees unless the vacancy is filled by a special election as provided by statute c during the period from the time that the vacancy occurs until a mayor is elected and has qualified the vacancy may be filled by the election of an acting mayor by the board of trustees d the acting mayor shall be paid the mayors salary for the period of time such person shall serve as acting mayor and such person may be referred to as the mayor  mayor pro tempore if a temporary absence or disability of the mayor incapacitates the mayor from the performance of the mayors duties but does not create a vacancy in the office the board of trustees shall elect 1 of its members to act as mayor pro tempore the mayor pro tempore during this absence or disability shall perform the duties and possess all the rights and powers of the mayor no additional salary or compensation shall be paid the mayor pro tempore for acting as mayor pro tempore  appointments by mayor the mayor with the advice and consent of the board of trustees shall appoint such boards commissions committees or other agencies as may be authorized by ordinance or resolution of the board of trustees or as may be authorized by statute  oath before entering upon the duties of the mayors office the mayor shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute  compensation the mayor shall receive such annual compensation as is fixed by the board of trustees from time to time by the adoption of an ordinance in accordance with the illinois constitution and state statute  additional powers and duties in addition to the powers otherwise described in this division the mayor shall perform all such other duties and acts and have all additional powers that are or may be prescribed by the law of the state or the ordinances of the village deputy clerks 65 ilcs 5313595 secs 21182130  reserved division 4  village manager footnotes  6  state law reference managerial form of municipal government 65 ilcs 5511 et seq creation of office the office of village manager is hereby created  appointment  qualifications the village manager shall be appointed by majority vote of the mayor and board of trustees the manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of such persons executive and administrative qualifications without regard to such persons political beliefs at the time of the managers appointment the manager need not be a resident of the village or of the state but during the managers tenure of office the manager shall reside within the village  powers and duties the village manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the village the manager shall be responsible to the mayor and board of trustees for the proper administration of all the affairs of the village the manager shall have the power and is required to 1 enforce all laws and ordinances of the village 2 attend all meetings of the mayor and board of trustees the manager shall have the right to take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the board of trustees but shall have no right to vote the manager shall be entitled to notice of all special and regular meetings of the board of trustees 3 recommend to the mayor and board of trustees such measures as in the managers judgment the manager deems to be in the best interests of the village 4 appoint suspend or remove all department heads appointed staff and employees of the village and prepare any and all documents commensurate with this authority this shall not be taken to include the elected officers consultants retained by the mayor and board of trustees the corporation counsel and the assistant corporation counsels employees in the uniformed fire and police service appointed by the board of fire and police commissioners the plan commission and all appointed board and commission members and other committees created by the mayor and board of trustees such appointments suspensions or removals shall be based upon the merit and fitness of such officer or employee without regard to political belief or affiliation the manager may authorize the head of a department or office to appoint suspend or remove subordinates in such department or office 5 exercise control of all departments and divisions except the corporation counsel and assistant corporation counsels now in existence or that may hereafter be created by the mayor and board of trustees except as limited or restricted by ordinance 6 make recommendations to the mayor and board of trustees concerning compensation for each appointive office and position in the village service except the corporation counsel and assistant corporation counsels including minimum intermediate and maximum rates 7 recommend to the mayor and board of trustees the creating consolidating and combining of officers positions departments or units of the administrative and executive departments of the village 8 investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the administration of the government of the village and services maintained by the public utilities in the village and the manager shall see that all franchises permits and privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed 9 be the general purchasing agent of the village  provided however that the manager shall appoint a purchasing agent who shall serve under the direction of the director of finance but subject to the authority of the village manager except where specific provision to the contrary is made by law or by the mayor and board of trustees the village manager shall be responsible for purchasing all materials supplies and equipment authorized by the board of trustees or for which funds are provided in the budget but the manager may not purchase any item which exceeds any appropriation until the board of trustees has increased the appropriation purchases of goods and services shall be made consistent with this state statutes the village manager may issue rules and regulations covering requisitions and the transaction of the business of purchasing 10 sign on behalf of the village any contract authorized by the mayor and board of trustees except where the board of trustees this ordinance or statute directs that some other officer shall do so it shall be the duty of the village manager to see that all terms of any contract to which the village is a party are fully performed by all parties thereto 11 prepare or cause to be prepared on or before may 1 of each year a budget of estimated funds necessary to defray the expenditure of the village for the fiscal year  prepare or cause to be prepared the annual appropriation ordinance in time for consideration by the mayor and board of trustees during the first month of the fiscal year  and prepare or cause to be prepared the tax levy ordinance and upon enactment thereof file a certified copy with the county clerk 12 cause the village treasurer to submit to the mayor and board of trustees promptly following the end of the fiscal year a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the village for the fiscal year 13 present or cause the director of finance to present to the mayor and board of trustees each month a statement showing the exact financial condition of the village as of the end of the preceding month and showing amounts appropriated amounts expended and unexpended balances in the several items of appropriation 14 keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the village and the location of such property the manager shall be responsible for the care and custody of all village property which is not by law assigned to some other officer or body for care and control 15 devote entire time to the discharge of the managers official duties 16 perform such other lawful duties as may be required by resolution or ordinance of the mayor and board of trustees  compensation the village manager shall receive such compensation as the mayor and board of trustees shall fix from time to time by ordinance  acting village manager if the village manager shall be absent from the village or incapacitated for a period of 30 consecutive days from performing the duties of the managers position a qualified person may be appointed by the mayor and board of trustees to act as manager during such absence or incapacity with all the powers and duties of that office and the compensation to be paid such acting village manager shall be fixed by the mayor and board of trustees  vacancies  manager pro tempore in case of a vacancy of the office of village manager the mayor and board of trustees shall appoint a manager pro tempore who shall possess the powers and duties of the manager until such time as a new manager is appointed no manager pro tempore shall hold the position as such for more than 4 months and no appointment of a manager pro tempore shall be renewed the compensation to be paid to such manager pro tempore shall be fixed by the mayor and board of trustees  removal the board of trustees may remove the village manager at any time with or without cause by a majority vote of the entire board of trustees  secs 21382160  reserved division 5 of a corporation counsel and assistant corporation counsels together with such additional employees as the corporation counsel may from time to time require in the performance and discharge of the duties of the corporation counsel  appointment of attorneys and other personnel a the corporation counsel and assistant corporation counsels shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the state shall be members of the bar in good standing and shall otherwise be qualified by law to serve as the attorneys for the village  duties of corporation counsel a the corporation counsel shall be the head of the office of the corporation counsel and shall have full charge of all the law business of the village and shall be and act as legal advisor of the mayor and board of trustees and of the several officers boards commissions and departments of the village the corporation counsel shall represent the village in any legal action or matter to which the village is a party or in which the village has an interest before any court tribunal or commission unless excused by the mayor and board of trustees b the corporation counsel shall regularly attend the meetings of the board of trustees  however the corporation counsel may designate an assistant to attend any meeting and empower such assistant to act in the place and stead of the corporation counsel c the corporation counsel shall direct the other members of the law department and shall call upon other members of the legal staff for assistance in performing the duties required of the corporation counsel and may with the appointed by the village manager 03 qualifications of fire chief no person shall be eligible to hold the office of fire chief unless such person shall possess technical training and knowledge and experience in the matters of firefighting and fire prevention so as to reasonably qualify in such matters this shall encompass thorough knowledge of policies regulations and requirements of a fire department and of fire prevention laws and ordinances  considerable knowledge of the principles of public administration with reference to departmental personnel and budget administration  ability to analyze the effectiveness of the department and to correlate its development with changing conditions in the village  ability to plan assign and direct the work of a number of subordinate operating units under emergency conditions  ability to meet tactfully and effectively with public officials and the general public and to present ideas clearly in oral or written form  and ability to provide effective leadership and to maintain harmonious relationships in the department also considerable experience in a supervisory firefighting position with the responsibility for a major phase of departmental administration and graduation from an accredited university or college with at least a bachelors degree supplemented by formal fire training and certification may be required as may be determined by the village 04 duties of fire chief the fire chief shall perform the following duties 1 the fire chief shall have the custody subject to the direction of the village manager of all village property and equipment pertaining to the fire department 2 the fire chief shall have control and direction of all personnel of the village fire department 3 the fire chief shall cause to be investigated the cause origin and circumstances of any fire or explosion involving a loss of life injuries to persons or destruction of or damage to property when in the opinion of the fire chief reasonable cause exists that the fire or explosion may have been of incendiary origin the fire chief shall have the authority to take custody of all physical evidence relating to the cause of the fire or explosion and to continue the investigation to conclusion proprietary information as identified by the occupant which may relate to trade secrets or processes shall not be part of the public record except as may be directed by a court of law or applicable state statute 4 the fire chief shall from time to time during the year examine the condition of fire apparatus and fire stations and report such information to the village manager 5 the fire chief shall at least once in 6 months or as deemed necessary inspect or cause to be inspected all buildings except for singlefamily residential property for the purpose of determining the safety of such buildings including the sufficiency and adequacy of detection suppression and alarm systems of doors passageways aisles stairways and generally facilities for egress in case of fire or other accident the overloading of floors and storage of combustibles cross reference inspections for fire hazards  5036 6 the fire chief or a designated subordinate shall have the right to enter upon the premises wherein any fire has occurred if necessary in order to investigate the origin of the fire 7 the fire chief shall attend all major fires occurring in the village in the case of the fire chiefs absence from any fire it shall be the duty of a deputy fire chief or the highest ranking officer in command of the fire companies at such fire to take charge of the department such officer shall have and exercise all powers of the fire chief 8 the fire chief shall cause to be examined all buildings and walls reported dangerous or damaged by fire or accident and shall when requested by the village manager or designee also examine all buildings under application to raze enlarge alter or rebuild and make a report of the condition thereof as requested 9 the fire chief shall make rules and regulations not inconsistent with the board of fire and police commissioners rules and regulations concerning the fire department  provided receive no additional pay for their services as such special police officers such special police officers shall possess only the powers and privileges specified by the chief of police and shall be subject to all the rules and regulations governing the police department all applicable village ordinances and all applicable statutes and regulations of the state pertaining to police officers of the village the chief of police shall not authorize any individual special police officer to use a weapon in the course of performing the duties of the special police appointment unless the individual appointee has previously and satisfactorily completed a course of training in the use of weapons in the performance of police duties which course of training must be authorized and approved for the individual prior to the appointment as a special police officer c appointment of guards for special duty the village manager may on application of any person showing the necessity thereof appoint and swear in any additional number of special police officers to do special duty at any fixed place within the village at the charge and expense of the person by whom the application was made persons so appointed shall conform and shall be subject to all rules and regulations governing the police department and to such special rules regulations and restricted powers and privileges as the chief of police may make concerning such special police officers the chief of police may at any time with the consent of the village manager remove or discharge from service any such special police officers without assigning any cause therefor d reports of appointments it shall be the duty of the village manager or designee to report to the board of fire and police commissioners and to the mayor and board of trustees at the first regular meeting of the mayor and board of trustees held after any appointment all appointments of special police officers made by the village manager or the police chief the duration of and the reasons for the appointments of special police officers 07 lost stolen or seized property a custodian one of the employees of the police department shall be designated by the chief of police to be the custodian of lost and stolen property such person shall at all times be under the supervision and direction of the chief of police as the custodian such person shall take possession of all property seized or taken by the police b disposition the custodian shall keep a record of all property which may be seized or otherwise taken possession of by the police department if such property shall not be claimed by the rightful owner and possession surrendered to such owner within 30 days from the date of such seizure or taking by the police the custodian shall proceed to dispose of such property as follows 1 in all cases where any lost or unclaimed property is delivered into the custody of the police department by any person not the owner thereof the property shall at the end of the 30day period be delivered to the finder for purposes of disposition by the finder as provided in 765 ilcs 102027102036 at the option of the finder the village may for its own account proceed to dispose of the property in accordance with the provisions of illinois compiled statutes 2 where the police department is the original finder or taker of lost or stolen property or where the police department obtains possession of any unclaimed property arising out of a court proceeding in connection with which such property was seized then upon such property remaining unclaimed for the 30day period the custodian shall publish or cause to be published in the official newspaper of the village a description of such property together with the date of seizure or the taking of possession thereof and shall give notice that if such property be not claimed by the rightful owner or owners thereof within 10 days from the date of such publication such property will be sold at public auction at such places as the chief of police may direct and in such manner as to expose to the inspection of bidders all property so offered for sale provided that if such unclaimed property is deemed by the chief of police to be of use to the police department the property may be taken for the use of the department 3 in addition to the publication of notice provided for in this subsection the custodian of lost and stolen property shall post or cause to be posted in at least 3 public places in the village a copy of the notice published in the official newspaper and shall make a record of the date when such publication and the posting of notices are made if within 10 days from the date of such publication and posting no claim for such property described in such notices shall have been made by the rightful owner thereof the custodian shall proceed to sell such property at public auction c weapons none of provisions of this section shall apply to pistols revolvers knives slingshots metallic knuckles or other deadly weapons of like character but all such weapons shall be either destroyed or retained for use by the police department d disposition of proceeds of sale the proceeds of any ban act 5 ilcs 4251 et seq  pecuniary interest in contracts 65 ilcs 5486 declaration of policy the proper operation of democratic government requires that public office not be used for personal gain in recognition of this goal there is hereby established the code of ethics set out in this article for all officials and employees whether elected or appointed paid or unpaid the provisions and purpose of this article and such rules and regulations as may be established pursuant to this article are hereby declared to be in the best interest of the village  conflict of interest generally a no elected official or other official or employee whether paid or unpaid shall engage in any business or transaction or shall have a financial or other personal interest direct or indirect which is incompatible with the proper discharge of such persons official duties in the public interest or would tend to impair such persons independence of judgment or action in the performance of such persons official duties personal as distinguished from financial interest includes an interest arising from blood or marriage relationships or close business association b the following are hereby designated as constituting conflicts of interest 1 engaging in or accepting private employment or rendering services for private interests when such employment or service is incompatible with the proper discharge of official duties or would tend to impair independence of judgment or action in performance of official duties 2 appearing on behalf of private interests before any agency of the village except without compensation and only in the course of duties as a representative of the electorate or in the performance of public or civic obligations 3 failing to disclose the full nature and extent of a substantial or controlling financial interest in or any substantial dealings as a debtor creditor or otherwise in connection with any business entity contracting with the village for the sale of real estate materials supplies or services such official with or without such disclosure shall refrain from voting upon or otherwise participating in any such transaction contract or sale  disclosure of income an official or employee whether paid or unpaid who has a direct or indirect financial or other interest in any transaction the disposition of which may be influenced by such persons official position or action shall disclose all sources of income and the nature and extent of any personal interest in such transaction as an officer agent member or owner of any business entity or other association which is subject to regulation by the village such disclosure shall remove any presumption of conflict of interest for any transaction where the information disclosed is pertinent  appearing before agency in which formerly employed it shall be improper for any administrative member of the staff or any appointive employee serving on the plan commission or the zoning board of appeals to appear within a period of 2 years after the termination of such persons employment from the village or the termination of the appointive officials term of office before the agency in which such official or employee was formerly employed in connection with any case or other matter with which such official or employee was directly connected while an official or employee or as a member of the plan commission or zoning board of appeals  enforcement nothing contained in this article shall create or detract from the civil or criminal liability of any public official or employee or any other laws or ordinances or procedures rules and contracts violations of any provisions of this article shall constitute a cause for suspension removal from office or employment or other disciplinary action by the appropriate authority in the case of elected officials a violation shall result in the issuance of a public proclamation calling upon the affected official to resign the officials office board of trustees a the commission shall be comprised of three members appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the board of trustees no person shall be appointed as a member of the commission who is related either by blood or by marriage up to the degree of first cousin to any elected officer of the village the mayor shall designate one of the appointees to act as chairperson b all commissioners shall be appointed to 3year terms and shall serve until their successors are duly appointed commissioners may be reappointed to serve subsequent terms c meetings shall be held at the call of the chairperson or any 2 commissioners a quorum shall consist of two commissioners and official action by the commission shall require the affirmative vote of two members d the mayor with the advice and consent of the board of trustees may remove a commissioner in case of incompetence neglect of duty or malfeasance in office e the commission shall have the following powers and duties 1 to promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its duties and the exercise of its powers  2 to investigate conduct hearings deliberations and issue recommendations for the imposition of penalties or disciplinary actions the commission shall act only upon the receipt of a written complaint signed and notarized alleging a violation of this not upon its own prerogative  3 to receive information from the public pertaining to its investigations and to require additional information and documents from officers who may have violated the provisions of this   and 4 to compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production of books and papers pertinent to an investigation it is the obligation of all officers and employees of the village to cooperate with the commission during the course of its investigations failure or refusal of an officer to cooperate with requests by the commission shall constitute grounds for a recommendation of penalty or discipline the commission shall notify the village manager of any request by it for a village employee to appear before it to be interviewed by an agent of the commission or to provide any documents f the powers and duties of the commission are limited to matters clearly within the purview of this the mayor and board of trustees shall take action on any recommendation made by the commission the mayor and board of trustees are not bound by the recommendation of the commission and may impose any penalty or discipline including but not limited to discharge as they deem appropriate in accordance with law any action taken by the mayor and board of trustees in relation to a recommendation by the commission is a final decision for purposes of judicial review g the commission shall comply with the following procedures 1 within 7 business days after the receipt of a complaint the commission shall send by certified mail return receipt requested a notice to the respondent that a complaint has been filed against him or her and a copy of the complaint the commission shall send by certified mail return receipt requested a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant within 7 business days after receipt by the commission the notices to the respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date time and place of the meeting to determine the sufficiency of the complaint and to establish whether probable cause exists to proceed  2 the commission shall meet to review the sufficiency of the complaint and if the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this to determine whether there is probable cause to proceed based on the evidence presented by the complainant the meeting may be closed to the public to the extent authorized by the open meetings act the commission shall issue notice to the complainant and the respondent within 7 business days of the commissions ruling on the sufficiency of the complaint and if necessary on probable cause to proceed  if there is a determination of probable cause then the commissions notice to the parties shall include a hearing date scheduled within 3 weeks if the complaint is deemed not sufficient to allege a violation or if there is no determination of probable cause then the commission shall send by certified mail return receipt requested a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint and that notice shall be made public  3 on the scheduled date the commission shall conduct a hearing on the complaint and shall allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence the hearing may be closed to the public only if authorized by the open meetings act  4 within 30 days after the date the hearing or any recessed hearing is concluded the commission shall either i dismiss the complaint or ii issue a recommendation to the mayor and board of trustees for the imposition of a penalty or discipline or both the particular findings in the case any recommendation for a penalty or discipline shall be a matter of public information  5 if a complaint is filed during the 60 days preceding the date of any election at which the respondent is a candidate the commission shall render its decision as required under subsection h1g2 within 7 calendar days after the complaint is filed and during the 7 days preceding that election the commission shall render such decision before the date of that election if possible  and 6 a complaint alleging the violation of this act must be filed within one year after the alleged violation 2 the village
