state law reference employees and employment 65 ilcs 51011 et seq general policy  title of article it is the policy of the united states government to ensure the maximum participation of all available workers in production regardless of race creed color or national origin religion age sex sexual orientation or disability in the firm belief that the democratic way of life within the nation can be defended successfully only with the help and support of all groups within its borders including the village by eliminating discrimination in public and private employment the village in furtherance of this democratic objective hereby enacts the regulations of this article to be known as the fair employment practices   penalties  additional remedies a any person who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to the penalties provided in in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for b in addition to all other remedies for the violation of this article any person having engaged in discrimination in violation of this article shall be barred from doing business or contracting with the village for such period of time as the mayor and board of trustees shall determine to a maximum of 2 years  discrimination by village departments or officials it shall be unlawful for any department of the village or any village official or such officials agent or employee for or on behalf of the village to refuse to employ or discharge any person otherwise qualified on account of religion age disability race sex color creed or national origin  to discriminate for the same reasons in regard to tenure terms or conditions of employment  to deny promotion or increase in compensation solely for these reasons  to publish an offer of employment based on such discrimination  or to adopt or enforce any rule or employment policy which discriminates between employees on account of race sex color religion creed national origin disability or age consistent with the pension retirement and other laws of the state  discrimination by contractors and suppliers every contract which the village or any of its departments is a party to or solicits for shall be conditioned upon the requirement that all suppliers of materials and services and all contractors and their subcontractors and all labor unions or labor organizations that furnish skilled unskilled or craft union skilled labor or that perform any such labor or services and all financial institutions that maintain any financial relationship under such contract do not discriminate against any other person by reason of race creed color religion national origin age sex or disability with respect to the hiring application for employment tenure terms or conditions of employment of any person  duty of contractors and suppliers regarding employment policy every supplier of materials and services and all contractors doing business with the village shall be an equal opportunity employer  inspection of records of contractors and suppliers the village shall have the right to inspect records of prospective contractors bidders or suppliers to ensure that they are equal opportunity employers as provided for by federal law and federal executive order and to ensure their compliance with the requirements and obligations of the illinois human rights act 775 ilcs 51101 et seq which act is incorporated in this article by reference  compliance by contractors and suppliers a certification of employment policy every supplier of materials and services and every contractor who shall be a party to a contract with the village shall by affidavit certify that it is the suppliers or contractors policy to recruit hire train upgrade promote and discipline the suppliers or contractors employees without regard to race creed color religion age sex or national origin or disability b regulations to be incorporated in contracts the provisions of shall be incorporated as material parts of all contracts to which the village is a party  administration and enforcement the administration of this article shall be the responsibility of the village manager except for the authority of the mayor and board of trustees the manager shall have the power to receive investigate and seek to adjust complaints of discriminatory practices prohibited by this article initiate and hold hearings and make findings of fact and recommendations to the mayor and board of trustees concerning any practices or allegations of such practices  complaints  hearings a any person claiming to be personally aggrieved by discriminatory practices prohibited by this article or to have personal knowledge of such practices may make a complaint in writing to the village manager such complaints shall be signed and notorized all complaints shall be investigated by the manager before a hearing is ordered b hearings shall be conducted by the manager or person designated by the manager hearings shall be held only after 10 days written notice to the respondent which shall include copies of the complaint or allegations all respondents shall be provided full opportunity to present evidence and to cross examine witnesses and may be represented by counsel c after a hearing where the manager or person designated by the mayor finds by a preponderance of the evidence that discrimination has been practiced by the respondent and after reasonable attempts to adjust the complaint have failed the manager shall transmit a written copy of the findings and recommendations to the mayor and board of trustees which shall act on the creation there is hereby created and established an executive department of the village which shall be known as the skokie emergency services and disaster agency the word agency when used in this article shall mean the emergency services and disaster agency for the village  membership all members of the agency shall be appointed by the village manager the agency shall consist of a coordinator deputy coordinator and such other persons as the functions of the agency shall require  vacancies the village manager is authorized to fill any vacancy which may arise in the agency  coordinator and deputy coordinator a the coordinator shall be the coordinating head of the agency and shall be charged with and have direct responsibility for the organization administration training and operation of the agency subject to the direction and control of the village manager b in the event of the absence resignation death or inability of the coordinator to serve the deputy coordinator shall act as and perform the duties of the coordinator until another coordinator is appointed as provided in this article  term of members the term of office of each member of the agency shall be for an undetermined term and members shall be subject to discharge with or without cause  oath of members every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the agency shall before entering upon such persons duties subscribe to the following oath which shall be filed with the director i ___________ do solemnly swear or affirm that i will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the constitution of the united states and the constitution of the state of illinois and the territory institutions and facilities thereof both public and private against all enemies foreign and domestic  that i take this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion  and that i will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which i am about to enter and i do further swear or affirm that i do not advocate nor am i nor have i been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the united states or of this state by force or violence  and that during such time as i am affiliated with the skokie emergency services and disaster agency i will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the united states or of this state by force or violence  office space the village manager is authorized to designate office space in the village hall andor elsewhere as may be provided by the mayor and board of trustees for use by the agency  levy of tax for emergency preparedness purposes the mayor and board of trustees may make an appropriation for emergency preparedness purposes and may levy therefor a tax not to exceed $005 per $10000 of the assessed value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes as provided by the illinois emergency management agency act 20 ilcs 33051 et seq  compensation of members all members of the agency shall receive such compensation as may be authorized by the mayor and board of trustees  payment of expenses expenses for the operation and conduct of the affairs of the agency shall be paid from funds provided for that purpose in the annual appropriation ordinance and budget for the village  adoption of rules of order and procedures the agency may adopt rules of order and procedures for the conduct of its business  annual report the agency chair or other designated member shall report in writing during the villages annual budget process to the mayor and board of trustees the report shall cover the activities of the agency for the preceding year  functions  duties a the functions of the agency shall be to protect the public health and safety of persons within the village and to prevent minimize repair and alleviate injury or damage resulting from disasters caused by enemy attack sabotage or other hostile action or by fire flood or natural causes generally b the agency shall perform the duties within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the village emergency preparedness plan as directed by the village manager and the state emergency services management agency programs prepared under the direction of the governor and the orders rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor and in addition shall perform such duties as may be required pursuant to any reciprocal mutual aid arrangements entered into with any other municipality pursuant to the provisions of the illinois emergency management agency act 20 ilcs 33051 et seq  mobile support team a the coordinator of the agency with the advice and consent of the village manager shall create a mobile support team composed of an indeterminate number of qualified persons whose functions shall be to aid and reinforce local agency organizations in areas stricken by such disaster as enumerated in this article and such team shall be subject to serve at the call of the governor or the director of the state emergency services and disaster agency as provided by statute b the coordinator with the approval of the village manager shall designate from among the membership of such mobile support team 1 person to act as the leader thereof c the leader under the direction and control of the coordinator shall be responsible for the organization administration training and operation of the mobile support team d any member of the mobile support team who is a paid employee or officer of the village while serving on a call to duty or for training exercises by the governor or state director shall receive the compensation and have the powers duties rights privileges and immunities incidental to such members employment or office any member who is not a paid employee or officer of the village while serving on a call to duty or for training exercises by the governor or state director shall be entitled to receive the compensation and benefits which are provided by statute  shelter managers a in case of national state or locally declared emergencies public shelter managers appointed by the coordinator shall open public shelters take charge of all stocks of food water and other supplies stored in such shelters admit the public according to the villages shelter use plan and take whatever control measures are necessary for the protection and safety of the occupants b shelter managers are authorized to use or cause to be used reasonable restraint against those who refuse to cooperate with the routine of shelter living under emergency conditions any person who refuses to carry out the orders of the shelter manager and the shelter managers appointed staff shall be subject to the penalties provided in in addition to any other penalty specifically provided for  agreements with other municipalities the coordinator may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other municipal corporations or political subdivisions of the state but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the mayor and board of trustees  emergency action a if the governor declares an emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the united states or the occurrence within the state of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action or natural causes it shall be the duty of the village emergency services and disaster agency to cooperate fully with the state emergency management agency and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law b the village manager shall have the authority to declare the existence of an emergency if it is deemed necessary to declare the existence of an emergency without delay the village manager and in the managers absence the coordinator may do so but such action shall be subject to ratification by the board of trustees at its next meeting c declarations of emergency initiated by the village manager or coordinator shall be valid for a 7day period the village manager or coordinator shall have the authority to execute extensions of the initial declaration in increments of 7 days each until the emergency precipitating the declaration has been brought under control  reimbursement by state the village department of finance may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any reimbursement made by the state to the village for expenses incident to training members of the agency as prescribed by the state emergency management agency director compensation for services and expenses of a mobile support team while serving outside the village in response to a call by the state emergency services and disaster agency and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to agency activities as provided by law  purchases and expenditures a the mayor and board of trustees may on recommendation of the agency coordinator with the concurrence of the village manager authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster and to protect the public health and safety protect property and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster b in the event of any disaster the agency coordinator is authorized on behalf of the village subject to the approval of the village manager to procure such services supplies equipment or materials as may be necessary in view of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations in accordance with the authority granted by the illinois emergency management agency act 20 ilcs 33051 et seq except however if the board of trustees meets at such time the coordinator shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body  prohibited acts it shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct hinder or delay or attempt to obstruct directly or indirectly any member of the agency in the performance of the members duties or in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article or to do any act prohibited by any rule or regulation issued pursuant to the authority contained in this article it shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear carry exhibit or display any emblem insignia or any other means of identification as a member of the agency unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by an authorized village officer  disaster preparedness team a there is hereby created a disaster preparedness team as designated by the village manager a representative of the american red cross shall be a member of the team the village manager and mayor shall be ex officio members of the team b the team shall meet at the call of the chair and advise the coordinator on all matters pertaining to emergency preparedness c the members of the team shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for such reasonable and necessary expenses as they actually incur in the performance of their duties in accordance with the villages budget process  secs 29722990  reserved article ix determining whether or not that person or business entity should be disqualified pursuant to this division the hearing officer shall be designated by the mayor and board of trustees b conduct of hearing evidence shall be limited to the factual issues raised by the notice persons with relevant information shall testify under oath before a certified reporter the hearing officer may refuse to hear cumulative evidence and the hearing officer shall moderate the hearing strict rules of evidence shall not apply to the proceedings but the hearing officer shall strive to elicit the facts fully and in credible form the affected person or business entity may be represented by an attorney c decision  order of disqualification at the conclusion of the testimony the hearing officer shall make a finding of whether or not the person or business entity falls within this division based upon a greater weight of the evidence disqualification shall be ordered upon a finding that the person or business entity falls within any subsection of the hearing officer shall mail a written copy of the finding to the person or business entity affected by certified mail return receipt requested d pending a review by the review board the person or business entity affected by the disqualification order may file with the village clerk written exceptions to the hearing officers findings exceptions must be filed within 10 days of the notice of appeal no oral presentation shall be made to the review board e recommendation by review board the review board shall review the written record tangible evidence the hearing officers finding and the written exceptions and shall expeditiously vote to recommend affirmance or reversal of the hearing officers finding to the mayor and board of trustees at single certificate to be kept by the administrator attesting to the correctness of all violation notices produced by the device while it was under the persons control in the case of an automated traffic law violation a determination must be made by a technician based on an inspection of recorded images that the vehicle was being operated in violation of of the ivc the technician shall execute the appropriate form certifying that a determination of violation was made i the original or a copy of the violation notice or a printed record of the notice generated by a computer device showing the facts entered on the notice shall be retained by the administrator a violation notice issued signed and served in accordance with this a copy of the notice or the computer generated record shall be prima facie correct and shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the notice the notice copy or computer generated record shall be admissible in any subsequent administrative or legal proceeding without the need to provide foundation the person issuing or certifying the violation notice is not required to appear at an administrative or legal proceeding in order to have the violation notice admitted c3605  3 3172008 administrative adjudication each person to whom a violation notice is issued against a respondent shall have an opportunity for a hearing before an administrative hearing officer the hearing officer the hearing will be conducted at the request of the respondent on a scheduled date at which the respondent may contest the merits of the alleged violation a respondent may be represented by counsel at their own expense but need not secure such representation the formal or technical rules of evidence shall not apply at the administrative hearing however all evidence offered must be relevant to the issues raised the hearing officer shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the board of trustees the hearing officer shall not be an employee of the village the hearing officers compensation will be set by ordinance the hearing officer shall serve until such person is removed by the mayor or replaced by a subsequent appointment of a new hearing officer by the mayor with the consent of the board the hearing officer shall be an attorney in good standing that has been licensed to practice law in illinois for more than five years prior to the appointment and must demonstrate sufficient training and experience to serve in the capacity as a hearing officer in the event the hearing officer is unable to attend a scheduled hearing the corporation counsel may appoint an attorney to serve as a temporary hearing officer the hearing officer shall have the authority and powers that are necessary to conduct fair and impartial hearings including but not limited to the powers granted to an administrative law officer in b of the skokie village c3605  3 3172008  c3677  1 5182009 rights and duties of respondents each respondent shall have the rights and duties stated herein a a respondent shall upon issuance and service of the violation notice pursuant to this division have 21 days from the date of issuance of the notice to do one of the following 1 pay the amount of the fine indicated on the notice  2 request an administrative hearing either in person at village hall or by mail  or 3 contest the merits of the alleged violation in writing the proper information as specified on the instructions attached to the violation notice and all supporting documentation on behalf of the respondents position must be submitted to the administrator the submittal may be mailed or delivered to village hall in order to comply with the 21 day deadline referenced above the respondent must either appear at village hall to make the appropriate payment request or written contest no later than the 21st day after the issuance of the violation notice or if mailed the submittals must be postmarked with a date that is no later than the 21st day after the issuance of the violation notice b in the event the respondent pays the full amount of the fine within 21 days of the date of issuance of the violation notice then such payment shall be a final disposition of the violation c in the event a respondent makes a request for an administrative hearing within 21 days of the date of issuance of the violation notice whether made in person or by mail then the administrator shall schedule the violation to be heard at the next available hearing date the administrator shall provide written notice of the hearing date and time to the respondent by first class mail or in person d in the event a respondent submits a written contest of the violation notice within 21 days of the issuance of the violation notice the administrator shall submit the written contest together with all documentation provided by respondent and other relevant information to the hearing officer in the event a respondent does not submit a written contest within 21 days of the date the violation notice is issued the respondent is deemed to have waived the right to submit a contest by mail e in the event a respondent does not take any of the actions specified in paragraph a above then the administrator shall cause an additional notice hereinafter the late notice to be sent by first class mail to the respondent for violations other than seat belt or child passenger protection regulations the late notice shall be sent to at least one owner but may be sent to each and every owner of the vehicle if there are multiple owners naming them as additional respondents the late notice shall inform the respondents 1 that payment is late and a penalty for late payment is imposed  2 respondent must pay the fine and penalty for late payment schedule a hearing date to contest the violation or contest the violation in writing pursuant to the procedures stated in paragraph a3 above within 14 days of the date of the late notice otherwise a determination of liability will be issued by the hearing officer and a fine and penalty imposed up to $350  3 the ability to contest by mail has been waived  4 of all of the same information regarding the violation as required on the initial violation notice or attach a copy of the violation notice  and 5 that the failure to pay amounts owed or appear at a requested hearing shall result in a determination of violation liability and after the appropriate period for judicial review the amount of the fine and penalty for late payment shall become a debt due and owing the village f all hearing dates scheduled by the respondent are firm a respondent is entitled to reschedule a hearing date one time the request to reschedule must be made by a respondent or someone authorized in writing to act on the respondents behalf in person or in writing to the administrator prior to the hearing date all other requests to continue a hearing must be made before the hearing officer g unless an owner provides written notice of a new or different address the administrator may rely upon the address of each owner as indicated on the records kept by the secretary of state or similar office in another state as of the date of the issuance of the violation notice subsequent to the issuance of a violation notice it is the duty of each respondent and owner to keep his or her address of record current with the administrator c3605  3 3172008  c3677  1 5182009 defenses a the only defenses available to a respondent to contest a violation notice regarding standing or parking of a vehicle or the condition or use of vehicle equipment compliance other than for seat belt or child passenger protection regulations or an automated traffic law violation are as follows 1 the cited vehicle or license plate was stolen at the time the violation notice was issued  2 the facts alleged in the violation notice contain inaccurate information to the extent that the facts fail to establish that the violation occurred  3 the respondent was not the registered owner of the referenced vehicle on the date of the violation notice provided however a determination in favor of one respondent shall not have any affect on the liability of any other owner of the vehicle  or 4 other verifiable information exists which proves that the violation did not occur b the only defenses available to a respondent upon the issuance of a violation notice for failure to purchase or display a wheel tax license are as follows 1 the respondent did not own or lease the vehicle or trailer at the time the violation notice was issued or had not exceeded the period of time allowed for the purchase or display of the license pursuant to this   or 2 all owners of the vehicle or trailer are not required by state law to display or purchase a wheel tax license c3605  3 3172008 determinations by the hearing officer the hearing officer shall preside over all proceedings at the administrative hearing the hearing officer shall make a determination of violation liability or no liability based upon the facts presented at the hearing such determination shall be included in an order entitled hearing officers determination the standard of proof is a preponderance of the evidence a in the event a respondent makes a timely request for administrative hearing however respondent does not appear at the hearing or does not pay the fine prior to the hearing date the hearing officer shall make a determination of violation liability and enter the appropriate findings or orders imposing the fine b in the event the administrator has issued a late notice however respondent does not request a hearing contest the violation in writing or does not pay the fine and late penalty within 14 days of the late notice the hearing officer shall make a determination of violation liability and enter the appropriate findings or orders imposing the fine and penalties up to the maximums allowed by law c in the event a respondent has timely filed a written contest to the violation notice then the hearing officer shall review all information submitted by respondent and other relevant information presented by the administrator the hearing officer shall make a determination of liability or no liability solely based upon the documents and information presented and enter the appropriate findings or orders d in the event a respondent appears at an administrative hearing to contest or present a defense to the merits of the violation notice the hearing officer shall allow the respondent to present relevant testimony and documents or other evidence in support of respondents position the person issuing and serving the violation notice is not required to appear at the administrative hearing due to the properly prepared violation notice being deemed to be prima facie evidence of the facts stated therein the hearing officer shall make a determination of violation liability or no liability and enter the appropriate findings or orders in the event the hearing officer makes a determination of violation liability the appropriate order shall be mailed by the village via first class mail to respondent and to other owners if the other owners were given notice of the pending violation the order shall bear the date of mailing on its face and specify the amount owed for a fine and penalty for late payment incurred if any in the event the hearing officer determines that a respondent is not liable for the violation then the appropriate order shall be entered and made a part of the file if the finding of no liability was the result of a contest by mail then a copy of the order shall be mailed via first class mail to the respondent c3605  3 3172008  c3677  1 5182009 petition to set aside a determination whenever an administrative hearing is held for the purpose of determining the question of violation liability and the respondent does not appear the respondent may file a written petition with the administrator to set aside a hearing officers determination of violation liability a in order to have such petition considered by the administrator the respondent must file the petition with the administrator in person or by mail no later than 14 days after the date that the hearing officers determination of violation liability is mailed to respondent the date on the hearing officers determination informing the respondent of violation liability shall be presumed to be the date that the order was mailed unless another mailing date is indicated b the only grounds for setting aside the hearing officers determination are limited to i the respondent was not the owner of the vehicle referenced on the date of the alleged violation provided however such defense is not available for a seat belt or child passenger protection regulations  ii the fine and penalty if any is applicable was paid prior to the hearing  or iii an excusable reason for the failure to appear at the hearing or request a new date for a hearing supported by documents or other credible information upon which a new hearing date will be assigned by the administrator and notice of such date will be mailed to respondent c upon the administrators denial of a petition to set aside the hearing officers determination of liability or upon the expiration of the 14 day period for filing such petition without a filing being made the hearing officers determination is a final decision for purposes of judicial review the administrator shall notify the respondent of the decision on the petition via first class mail should the administrator assign a new hearing date pursuant to paragraph biii above then the determination is not considered a final decision should the respondent fail to appear at the newly assigned hearing date then the respondent shall not have the right to petition the administrator to set aside a subsequent determination of violation liability and the hearing officers determination of violation liability shall be a final decision for purposes of judicial review d a respondent that appears at the administrative hearing does not have the right to petition the administrator to set aside the hearing officers determination in such case the hearing officers determination is a final decision for purposes of judicial review e a respondent does not have the right to file a petition to set aside a hearing officers determination which is based upon the respondents failure to request a hearing or pay the fine and late penalty within 14 days of the late notice liability c3605  3 3172008 secs 2110121199  reserved article xiii  environmental policy purpose it is the policy of the village of skokie to work towards becoming a sustainable community c3652  1 1212008 strategy development a strategy that includes an action plan shall be developed to ensure steady progress towards becoming a sustainable community a successful strategy and action plan must be comprehensive across the village governmental activities and eventually embrace the conduct and behaviors of residents property owners and businesses c3652  1 1212008 environmental officer designated the village manager shall designate an employee to perform the functions of an environmental officer whose duties shall include coordinating compliance with the environmental best practices policy as stated in of this assist with environmental analysis or provision of information in the decisionmaking process the environmental officer may utilize the service of assistants and shall have such other duties as assigned by the village manager c3652  1 1212008 examination by decision makers all decisions made by the corporate authorities and executive staff the decision makers shall examine the outcome in relation to the sustainable and environmental policies goals and objectives the environmental best practices policy this examination shall consider the economical feasibility of such outcome utilizing alternative approaches before committing resources the environmental best practices policy shall apply to decisions relating to i village government operations and expenditures  and ii efforts or actions to encourage residents property owners and businesses including developers and contractors to adhere to the goals and objectives stated c3652  1 1212008 environment best practices policy the environmental best practices policy shall develop over time initially the policy requires that decision makers take into consideration the following goals and objectives a limit the amount of water fuels energy minerals wood fiber paper products plastics pesticides and chemicals used by the village to the minimum amount necessary to adequately deliver products and services to residents property owners and businesses this may be achieved by various techniques including but not limited to maximizing efficiencies or use of alternative resources b reduce the production and release of pollution combination of technology and product or process substitution c avoid adverse environmental consequences by protecting air and water quality water table natural conditions wildlife habitat and physical environment d evaluate the true cost of goods or products by factoring the useful life operation and maintenance costs and ultimate disposal costs for comparison purposes when cost considerations are nearly equal preference to contractors or vendors that use energy efficient or reused or recycled products should be a priority e recycle and reuse as much of the villages waste stream as is economically and technically feasible f explore and encourage water treatment methods that treat storm water as an asset for reuse and to recharge the ground water supply g associate with coalitions of governments and other organizations and entities to achieve the goals and objective c3652  1 1212008 environmental education and outreach program the village shall undertake an ongoing environmental education and outreach program designed to inform residents property owners and businesses that everyday individual actions do matter the program shall amongst other things a provide useful and actionable information  b explore sustainable opportunities and assist residents in living a more sustainable lifestyle  c improve the publics understanding of recycling opportunities  d encourage residents and others to present their ideas and suggestions to the sustainable environmental advisory commission or the village  and e establish a series of awards to be presented to residents property owners or businesses for actions consistent with the goals and objectives stated in of this c3652  1 1212008 secs 2120621230  reserved article xiv  sidewalk animal upon any public or private property in a menacing fashion or with an apparent attitude of attack that does not cause injury  or 2 behaves in a manner that a reasonable person would believe the following circumstances existed 1 the threatened person was committing or attempting to commit a crime or an act of physical harm against the owner or owners agent or member of its household  2 the threatened person was committing or attempting to commit a crime against the property of the owner or custodian of the animal including without limitation burglary vandalism or criminal trespass  3 the threatened person was tormenting abusing assaulting or physically threatening the animal or its offspring  4 the threatened domestic animal was attacking or threatening to attack the animal or its offspring  5 the threatened domestic animal or threatened person was on the property of the animals owner without consent of the property owner  6 the animal was responding to the infliction of pain or injury  7 the animal was protecting itself or its offspring  8 the animal is a service dog or a police dog and was performing its duties  9 the threatened domestic animal was running at large considered as a vicious animal pursuant to this chapter and the owner must comply at all times with each and every requirement and restriction established in this chapter pertaining to vicious animals the circuit court of cook county judge may require any or all of the following of the owner i pay a minimum fine of $50000  ii pay any and all veterinary or medical bills of the injured person or domestic animal arising out of the incident  iii have the animal surgically altered and microchipped within 10 days at the owners expense if not previously done  iv confine the animal within a building or a secure enclosure subject to the approval of the skokie health department  v have the vicious animal evaluated within 10 days by a certified dog trainer and complete training or other treatment as deemed appropriate by the expert the owner of the vicious animal shall be responsible for all costs associated with evaluations and training ordered under this subsection  vi obtain liability insurance coverage for the animal within 14 days of being ordered to do so in the amount of at least $150000 which coverage includes without limitation coverage for animal bites evidence of the required insurance must be provided to the village within the same 14 days this insurance must be maintained on this animal for the duration of its life while living within the corporate limits of the village of skokie in lieu of liability insurance the owner of a vicious animal may obtain a surety bond in the value of at least $150000 which must be maintained on this animal for the duration of its life while living within the corporate limits of the village of skokie 2 a vicious animal as determined by an administrative law officer or a circuit court of cook county judge shall only be the amount of $75000  ii pay any and all veterinary or medical bills of the injured person or domestic animal arising out of the incident  iii the owner shall be determined to be a problem pet owner 1212014 additionally said ordinance renumbered  1867 as  1866 secs 18671880  reserved article iv  beekeepingresidential only beekeeping permit required persons seeking to have and maintain a beehive or establish a honeybee apiary in the village of skokie shall first obtain a beekeeping permit applicants may be beekeepers on the residential property of another as long as all requirements have been satisfied and permission has been granted from the property owner to keep an apiary and verified in writing applications shall be submitted to the village manager or designee beekeeping permits are only available for residential property beekeepers who owned or operated a honeybee apiary within the village prior to the effective date hereof and who continue to do so after the effective date hereof shall have thirty 30 days after such effective date to apply for a beekeeping permit a at the time of application for a beekeeping permit the applicant shall 1 submit a scaled site plan of the proposed apiary showing placement of the beehives the flyway barrier and fences and compliance with all applicable requirements outlined in this   2 provide a certificate of insurance from property owners homeowners insurance company verifying that beekeeping is covered by the insurance policy covering the property where the apiary will be located  3 provide a certificate of completion or similar documentation from a beekeeping training course provided by an entity approved by the village of skokie the skokie health department shall maintain a list of approved courses beekeepers are required to stay current and demonstrate their knowledge of colony health and management  4 submit written consent from all neighbors on residential property that abuts the proposed location in a form provided by the village of skokie notification is not required for renewals 5 submit a properly executed hold harmless agreement between the applicant if the location of the apiary is owned by a 3rd party then the property owner as well and the village waiving any liability for any loss or injury resulting from the design construction or operation of the apiary in lieu of any zoning or building permits that may be associated with the construction of an apiary  6 pay a one hundred twentyfive dollar $12500 nonrefundable initial permit fee 7 provide written consent of the property owner if the apiary will be located on residential property not owned by the applicant the property owner will be required to sign the application as well b state registration beekeeper must within 30 days of installation of a colony into a beehive register their beehives with the illinois department of agriculture or as otherwise required by the state of illinois state registration must be maintained for the life of the beehive c expiration and renewal beekeeping permits shall be valid for up to one year all beekeeping permits expire on march 31st of each calendar year beekeepers must submit their renewal application at least twentyone 21 days prior to the expiration date a renewal permit shall be subject to the requirements in subsection 1881a13 and b as outlined in subsection 1881c with payment of a fifty dollar $5000 permit renewal fee c4015  2 1142013 apiary inspection by signing an application for a beekeeping permit the applicant and the residential property owner whereon the beehive is located authorizes the village manager or designee to enter onto that part of the property which contains the beehive or apiary for the limited purpose of inspecting the colony and apiary for compliance with this inspections will be conducted each year by the skokie health department as well other inspections as may be needed beekeepers must have their beehives inspected by the state of illinois apiary inspector at least every other year c4015  2 1142013 beehive type all honeybee colonies shall be kept in langstroth type beehives with removable combs which shall be kept in sound and usable condition c4015  2 1142013 apiary maintenance beekeepers shall keep all beekeeping equipment in good condition and secure unused equipment from weather potential theft vandalism or occupancy by migratory colonies a components beekeepers shall ensure that no bee comb wax or other materials are left upon the grounds of the beehive or apiary site beekeepers shall promptly store or dispose of any bee comb wax or other materials which have been removed from the beehive in a sealed container or within a building or other bee proof enclosure b water beekeepers shall ensure that a convenient source of water is available within ten 10 feet of the beehive at all times during the beehives active months march the water source must be maintained in a secure receptacle so as not to create a breeding site for mosquitoes c colony maintenance beekeepers shall monitor and maintain their colony or colonies so as not to become a nuisance colonies must be monitored at least twice a month from march 1st to november 30th c4015  2 1142013 aggressive behavior in any instance in which a colony exhibits overly aggressive behavior by stinging or attempting to sting without due provocation or exhibits an unusual disposition towards swarming it shall be the duty of the beekeeper to immediately contact the state apiary inspector or the skokie department of health c4015  2 1142013 beehive location apiaries may only be located and maintained in residential districts with detached residences occupied by the beekeeper a apiaries shall be located only in a rear yard at least sixty 60 feet from a front lot line b apiaries shall be located at least six 6 feet from a side property line c apiaries shall be located at least fifteen 15 feet from a property line that abuts a street rightofway d apiaries shall be located at least five 5 feet from a rear lot line that does not abut an alley e two apiary sites may not exist within six hundred 600 feet of each other f apiaries and beehives shall not be permitted on rooftops or balconies g beekeepers shall not keep more than five 5 colonies in their apiary on any property c4015  2 1142013 fencing and flyways a fencing the apiary shall be enclosed on all sides by a fence five 5 feet in height and shall be at least three 3 feet from the beehive on all sides fencing shall be constructed of a minimum nine 9 gauge woven mesh corrosion resistant material or a solid material the fence posts shall be constructed of decay and corrosion resistant material set in concrete the entrance to the apiary shall have a gate with a locked latch at least four 4 feet from the ground which shall be closed at all times when the beekeeper is not present b flyways each beehive entrance must have a flyway barrier which directs the honeybees upwards as they exit the beehive the distance between the beehive entrance and flyway barrier shall be no more than ten 10 feet the flyway barrier may be part of the fence surrounding the apiary but must be 6 feet in height and four 4 feet wide and constructed of a solid material that bees cannot fly c4015  2 1142013 signage beekeepers shall conspicuously post a weatherproof sign at least ten 10 inches by one 1 foot on all lot lines facing abutting properties and on the beehive or apiary fence outside of the latched gate with the statement state registered beehives on property or similar language that makes clear that bees are on the premises the sign must be visible and easily read from outside the property c4015  2 1142013 nontransferability a beekeeping permit shall not be assigned or transferred to any other person or to any other location no refund shall be granted for any unexpired period of a beekeeping permit c4015  2 1142013 revocation of beekeeping permit a the village manager shall have the authority to revoke a beekeeping permit issued under this village manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation of a beekeeping permit b the village manager is hereby given the authority to revoke the beekeeping permit if the village manager finds 1 the beekeeper has not complied with applicable codes ordinances statutes laws policies or rules and regulations 2 the beekeeper has made fraudulent false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the permit 3 the beekeeper owes the village fees outstanding fines or penalties c notice and hearing the village manager may revoke suspend or take other action with respect to a beekeeping permit in accordance with the following procedures 1 the village manager or designee shall send written notice of the intent to revoke a beekeeping permit by first class us mail or personal delivery setting forth the reasons for revocation 2 the notice shall state the effective date of the revocation which shall be no longer than thirty 30 days from the date of the notice and shall inform the beekeeper of the right to submit in writing within fifteen 15 days of the date of the notice either documentation to explain the past occurrences stated in the notice and to propose corrective action to eliminate the violations or request a hearing before the village manager 3 if the village manager accepts the corrective action proposed by the beekeeping permit holder the village manager shall respond in writing stating the conditions for continuing to hold the beekeeping permit and retracting or deferring the notice of intent to revoke or suspend the beekeeping permit 4 if the beekeeping permit holder requests a hearing the village manager shall hold a hearing within thirty 30 days of the date of the original notice at which hearing the beekeeper and representatives from the village shall have the right to present any evidence andor witnesses 5 the village manager conducting the hearing shall render a written decision within seven 7 days of the c2947  52906 10162000 secs 2218722210  reserved article viii  swimming pools footnotes  6  cross reference zoning ch 118 state law reference swimming pool and bathing beach act 210 ilcs 1251 et seq  swimming pool safety act 210 ilcs 130001 et seq definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning classes of swimming pools there shall be 6 classes of swimming pools 1 belowground pools 2 aboveground permanent pools which shall mean any swimming pool of a depth of 2 feet or more and which shall have attached a platform of 30 square feet or more or a walkway which is 24 inches or more in width circumscribing the pool 3 aboveground portable pools which shall mean any swimming pool of a depth of 2 feet or more and which shall have attached a platform of 30 square feet or less or a walkway which is less than 24 inches in width circumscribing the pool 4 wading pools which shall mean any portable or storable type pool having a depth not to exceed 2 feet or a capacity of 500 gallons such pools shall not be subject to the terms of this article except that they shall be located in rear and side yards only and shall be drained after each use 5 private residential swimming pools which shall mean a swimming pool located in or on premises used as a singlefamily dwelling unit or 2family dwelling unit used and intended to be used solely by the owner or lessee of the swimming pool and the owners or lessees family and friends invited to use it without payment of any fee or consideration 6 public pools which shall mean any other swimming pool other than a private residential swimming pool and excepting and excluding any swimming pool maintained and operated by the skokie park district 01 cross reference definitions generally  12 permit to construct a no person or organization shall proceed to construct a swimming pool or make structural alterations at any existing private or public pool without first having obtained a permit therefor issued and signed by the village manager or designee upon approval of the application no permit is required for the erection of a portable pool if the capacity of such pool is 500 gallons or less b applications for permits under this article shall be made to the village manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the village manager or designee the village manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant each application for a permit to construct a public pool shall be accompanied by an approval permit for the construction issued by the state department of public health in accordance with provisions of the state swimming pool law 03 permit to operate a an annual permit to operate a swimming pool is required for all swimming pools except for 1 and 2family residential pools b the application shall be made in writing to the village manager or designee an operation permit shall be renewed annually in may and whenever a pool is to be reopened for use after being closed down for a period longer than 3 months c public pools closed for a period of 1 year or longer shall apply for a permit to operate on a form issued by the village manager or designee d the village manager or designee shall make inspections of swimming pools before the annual permit to operate is granted an additional inspection shall take place within 2 weeks after the swimming pool is put into operation subsequent inspection of pools shall be made as desired by the village manager or designee inspection of 1 and 2family residential swimming pools shall be made upon request and then only after payment of the fee prescribed in however the village manager or designee may require the inspection of 1 or 2family residential swimming pools without the prior request of the swimming pool owner 04 permit fees the building and plumbing permit fees under this article shall be as set forth in of skokie park district pools are not subject to the fees 07 inspection and testing the village manager or designee shall have the right and authority to inspect any swimming pool and to check the operation thereof during reasonable daylight hours 08 authority to close pools if village manager or designee shall find after inspection that the operation of a swimming pool does not meet the hygienic sanitary and safety requirements of this article the representative shall direct that the pool shall be closed until the sanitary and safety requirements are met 09 location  offstreet parking a no portion of a private residential swimming pool shall be located at a distance less than 8 feet from any side or rear property lines and pools shall comply with the building line requirements pumps filters and pool water disinfection equipment installation shall be located at a distance not less than 8 feet from any property line and shall comply with the building line requirements b no permit shall be issued for a swimming pool until offstreet parking is provided as stipulated in the zoning  if offstreet parking cannot physically be provided for any existing improved property this restriction shall not apply 02 sanitary and equipment requirements for public pools public pools and their equipment and operation shall comply with the state department of public healths minimum sanitary requirements for swimming pools and bathing places the illinois swimming pool and bathing beach act 210 ilcs 1251 et seq 05 sanitary and equipment requirements for private residential pools a recirculation of water required all private residential swimming pools shall be of the recirculation type in which circulation of the water is maintained pool by pumps the water drawn from the pool being clarified and disinfected before being returned to the pool b materials  slope of side walls private residential swimming pool walls and floors shall be constructed of any impervious material which will provide a tight tank with white or light colored finish easily cleaned surfaces the floor or bottom surface of the pool shall have a nonslip finish as smooth as possible the sides and walls of the pool shall present a smooth finish and shall be vertical to a depth of at least 6 feet or shall have a slope or curvature meeting one of the following conditions 1 the pool wall may be vertical for 30 inches from the flood level below which the wall may be curved to the bottom with a radius at any point equal to the difference between the depth at that point and 30 inches 2 to a depth of 6 feet from flood level except as in subsection b1 of this section the wall slope shall not be less than 1 foot horizontal in 6 feet vertical c water pressure  slope of bottom private residential swimming pools shall be designed to withstand the water pressure from within and to resist the pressure of the earth when the pool is empty to a pressure of 2200 pounds per square foot the slope of the bottom of any part of a pool in which the water is less than 5 feet in depth shall not be more than 1 foot in each 7 feet the maximum slope where the water is 5 feet or more in depth shall not exceed 1 foot in 2 feet d walk area unobstructed walk areas not less than 24 inches wide shall be provided to extend around all belowground swimming pools the walk area shall be such as to be smooth and easily cleaned and of a nonslip construction the slope of the walks shall have a pitch of at least  inch to the foot designed so as to prevent back drainage from entering the pool e fence all private residential belowground and aboveground permanent swimming pools and all aboveground portable pools shall be completely enclosed by a 4foot fence erected along the periphery of the pool walks unless that portion of the yard area containing the pool is enclosed with a fence complying with the following all fence openings or points of entry into the pool area enclosure shall be equipped with gates the fence and gates shall be a height of 4 feet above the grade walk level and shall be constructed of a number 9 gauge woven wire mesh corrosionresistant material or of such material and design as approved for safety by the village manager or designee all gates shall be equipped with selfclosing and selflatching devices placed at the top of the gate and made inaccessible to small children all fence posts shall be decay or corrosionresistant this subsection shall also apply to any aboveground pool not equipped with liftup ladders or steps with a nonabsorbent ground base of not less than 6 square feet f steps and ladders two or more means of egress in pools over 1000 gallons in the form of steps or ladders shall be provided for all private residential swimming pools at least 1 such means of egress shall be located on a side of the pool at both the deep end and the shallow end treads of steps and ladders shall be constructed of nonslip material at least 3 inches wide for their full length steps and ladders shall have a handrail on both sides or a center rail may be provided on steps g skimmers in every private residential swimming pool at least 1 skimming device shall be provided for each 800 square feet of surface area or fraction thereof skimmers shall be located at least 30 feet apart the handhold must be no more than 9 inches above the normal water line skimming devices shall be built into the pool wall adequately remove floating oils and waste and meet the following general specifications 1 be designed for a flowof at least 30 gallons per minute and the total capacity of all skimmers on any pool shall be at least 20 percent of the required filter flow of the recirculation system 2 be automatically adjustable to variations in water level over a range of at least 3 inches 3 an easily removable and cleanable basket or screen all overflow water must pass shall be provided to trap large solids 4 the overflow weir shall be of a sufficient length to maintain a rate of flow of at least 20 gallons per minute per lineal foot of weir lip h water source no source of water other than that secured from the village waterworks distribution system shall be used in private residential swimming pools i circulation system private residential swimming pool water recirculation system inlets shall be located so as to produce so far as possible uniform circulation of water throughout the pool without the existence of dead spots carry pool bottom deposits to the outlets and discharge at a minimum depth of 10 inches below the pool overflow level a minimum of 1 recirculation system inlet shall be provided for every 800 square feet of surface area of the pool or less j equipment for adding water pools shall be equipped with a suitable facility for adding makeup water as needed there shall be no physical connection between the water supply line and the pool system if the makeup water is added directly to the pool the outlets shall be at least 6 inches above the flood level of the pool k water supply system the system supplying recirculating water and makeup water to the pool shall be constructed in conformance with regulations set up by village manager or designee l water outlets in private residential swimming pools 30 feet in width or less water circulation system outlets shall be located so as to provide at least 1 outlet at the deepest point in the pool all pool drain outlets shall be equipped with gratings having an area of opening not less than 4 times the cross sectional area of the outlet pipe the gratings shall be of such design so they cannot be readily removed m facilities for emptying pool pools shall be equipped with facilities for completely emptying the pool and the discharge of the pool water to the sewer shall be at a rate not exceeding 100 gallons per minute no direct connection shall be made to the sewer n draining pool during rainy periods water drained from the pool shall not be discharged during periods of rain or storms o required recirculation equipment private residential swimming pool recirculation systems shall consist of pumping equipment hair lint catchers and filters necessary pipe connections to the pool inlets and outlets and facilities and pipe connections necessary for backwashing filters p capacity of recirculation system every private residential swimming pool shall have a recirculation system with an hourly capacity equal to the pool volume divided by 18 q water pump each circulation system pump shall have a sufficient capacity to discharge the volume of water required for an 18hour turnover of the pool against the maximum head in the recirculating system r backwashing pumps pumps used for backwashing filters shall have sufficient capacity to provide a filter backwash rate of at least 10 gallons per minute per square foot of filter area s strainers and filters a hair and lint catcher or strainer shall be installed on the suction side of the circulation pump to prevent hair lint and other extraneous matter from reaching the pump filters hair and lint catchers shall be designed accessible and located so they can be easily dismantled for cleaning and inspection the design features shall be as follows 1 water shall pass strainer from the outside 2 the strainer shall be made of a noncorrosive material 3 the width or diameter of the strainer opening shall be not more than 18 inch 4 the area of the strainer opening shall be at least 5 times the crosssectional area of the inlet pipe to the strainer 5 the recirculating system shall contain rapid pressure filters gravity vacuum diatomite or other approved systems 6 sufficient filter area shall be provided to filter the entire contents of the pool in 18 hours at the rate of not more than 5 gallons per square foot of filter area per minute 7 the filter backwashing facilities shall be sufficient to backwash at the rate of 10 gallons per minute per square foot of filter area 8 all backwash water and effluents shall be discharged to the sewer indirect connection 9 pressure filters shall be equipped with readily accessible air relief valves loss of head or pressure gauges on the inlet and outlet pipes and an access head or hole large enough to permit inspection maintenance and repair work 10 sight glasses that can be easily removed for cleaning shall be provided in the effluent line from the filter unit t disinfection 1 equipment shall be provided for the disinfection of all pool water any disinfection method using materials other than chlorine compound shall be subject to the approval of the village manager or designee disinfection equipment installed for the use of chlorine compound shall have sufficient capacity to maintain free chlorine residual of 05 parts per million materials and testing equipment shall be provided to test chlorine residual 2 gaseous chlorination systems shall not be used as a disinfection method u nonresidential building that is vacant and any person maintaining operating or collecting rent for any nonresidential building that has become vacant shall within 30 days shall do the following 1 enclose and secure the building in a manner approved by the village buildings shall only be boarded after application and receipt of a permit except for emergencies such as fire or wind damage for which an application shall be filed within 48 hours of the board up a vacant building may not remain boarded longer than 90 days unless an extension of that time is part of a plan approved by the director  2 properties with 100 percent building vacancy shall have a sign affixed to the building indicating the name address and telephone number of the owner and the owners authorized agent the sign shall be no smaller than two 2 feet by two 2 feet but no larger than four 4 by four 4 feet and be placed in such a location so as to be legible from the nearest public street or sidewalk whichever is nearer in addition for buildings which are the subject of a foreclosure action or have been foreclosed on the name address and telephone number of the maintenance company shall be on the sign  3 maintain the property including any building on the property in a secure and closed condition  4 an alarm system shall be installed by the owner of any building that is 100 percent vacant no later than eleven 11 months after notification that the building is vacant the property owner shall pay for the alarm service one year in advance prior to the annual certificate of compliance renewal of the property or vacant tenant space the alarm service company and level of detection shall be subject to approval by the village manager or designee  5 install a knox rapid entry key box at all vacant buildingsunits within 30 days of vacancy commercial and industrial buildings that already have a knox box do not need to install a box for individual units  6 the owner of a vacant property with ground floor windows facing a street shall a window covering cover the windows with a window display or decorative screening approved by the village each window shall have at least 80 percent coverage so as to obscure a direct public view of the building interior allowable window coverage materials must be of one color and shall be in the form of one of the following 1 plastic film  2 horizontal pleated and vertical shades  3 pleated paper  4 a display of products with a backdrop which are sold by other businesses in a building art work or an alternative window covering may be permitted if submitted to and approved by the village manager or designee b window signage the only type of window sign that shall be allowed is a real estate sign for the sale or rental of that property that does not exceed 25 percent of the total of a window pane area only one sign shall be allowed per street frontage for a building a window sign shall not be allowed if a ground sign is used to advertise the sale or rental of the property additional window signs shall be allowed if the property is participating in the villages window covering program 7 maintain the building and property in compliance with the requirements of the most recently adopted international property maintenance zoning all other codes and ordinances of the village these regulations include but are not limited to the following a maintenance of parking areas 1 all parking areas shall be maintained at all times in broom clean condition without potholes broken wheel stops andor curbing or other surface irregularities 2 all landscaping shall be maintained in a flourishing condition free of weeds and debris and all dead landscaping shall be replaced 3 pavement markings shall be visible at all times and parking lot signage shall be readable at all times with the signpost maintained in an upright manner 4 all parking lot curbing shall be maintained and vehicle stop blocks securely mounted in their proper locations 5 compliance is required with all conditions of the villages private property fire lane sign maintenance program and the villages designation of private property handicapped parking spaces program 6 all area lighting shall be maintained in functioning condition drainage systems shall be maintained in a freeflowing working condition 7 it shall be unlawful to alter any aspects of an approved parking lot plan unless approval has been received director of engineering 8 parking areas shall be used exclusively for parking purposes and not for storage of vehicles boats trailers campers or other personal property 9 all parking lot drainage structures and facilities shall be maintained and in working order b maintenance of landscaping 1 all landscaping on public or private property that is part of an approved development plan shall be properly maintained in a vigorous growing condition by the owner of the property any landscaping which has deteriorated shall be replaced 2 all shrubbery shall be maintained to a height not to exceed 30 inches for a distance of 15 feet from any vehicular access point into or out of the site all trees planted near the drives on the property are required to have a ground clearance of 6 feet minimum to the bottom of the foliage 3 all property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of 6 inches in height all noxious weeds shall be prohibited weeds shall be defined as all grasses annual plants and vegetation other than trees or shrubs provided  however this term shall not include cultivated flowers or gardens c maintenance of exterior property areas 1 all property shall be maintained in a clean litter free safe and sanitary condition 2 all property shall be graded and maintained to prevent the erosion of soil and to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon or within any structure located thereon 3 all sidewalks walkways stairs driveways parking spaces and similar areas shall be kept in a proper state of repair and maintained free from hazardous conditions including ice and snow 4 no vehicles that are inoperable shall be permitted to be stored in the open 5 open offstreet parking shall be located upon an approved surface 6 there shall not be accumulations of litter decayed animal or vegetable matter trash rubbish rotting lumber appliances tires landscape waste bedding packing material abandoned vehicles or machinery scrap metal or any material in which flies mosquitoes diseasecarrying insects rats or other vermin may breed or which create a fire hazard 7 there shall be no active rodent infestation 8 stagnant water in which mosquitoes flies or other insects can multiply shall not be allowed 9 substances or things on the property emitting or causing any foul offensive noisome nauseous noxious or disagreeable odors effluvia or stenches extremely repulsive to the physical senses of ordinary persons which annoy discomfort injure or inconvenience the health of any appreciable number of persons within the village shall not be allowed 10 garbage paper products rubbish litter or any offensive substance shall not be allowed 11 marking carving or graffiti shall not be allowed on buildings fixtures or other structures on the property 12 the property shall not be used for nuisance activities d maintenance of building exterior 1 the exterior of a structure shall be maintained in good repair structurally sound and sanitary so as not to pose a threat to the public health safety or welfare 2 all exterior surfaces including but not limited to doors door and window frames cornices porches trim balconies decks and fences shall be maintained in good condition exterior wood surfaces other than decayresistant woods shall be protected from the elements and decay by painting or other protective covering or treatment peeling flaking and chipped paint shall be eliminated and surfaces repainted all siding and masonry joints as well as those between the building envelope and the perimeter of windows doors and skylights shall be maintained weather resistant and water tight all metal surfaces subject to rust or corrosion shall be coated to inhibit such rust and corrosion and all surfaces with rust or corrosion shall be stabilized and coated to inhibit future rust and corrosion oxidation stains shall be removed from exterior surfaces surfaces designed for stabilization by oxidation are exempt from this requirement 3 all exterior walls shall be free from dents holes breaks and loose or rotting materials  and maintained weatherproof and properly surface coated where required to prevent deterioration 4 all cornices belt courses corbels terra cotta trim wall facings and similar decorative features shall be maintained in good repair with proper anchorage and in a safe condition 5 after the removal of wall signs or other fixtures the wall shall be repaired andor painted to have the same surface color and finish as the rest of the building wall to which it was attached 6 every window skylight door and frame shall be kept in sound condition good repair and weather tight 7 all glazing materials shall be clean and maintained free from cracks holes or other defects 8 marking carving or graffiti shall not be allowed on buildings fixtures or other structures on the property 9 painted or color treated surfaces shall have a consistent surface color that is not faded chipped or discolored 10 buildings that have been approved by the appearance commission shall be maintained in accordance with the approved plan e maintenance of building interiors 1 the building shall remain vacant unless a certificate of occupancy is obtained for a new use 2 all interior fixtures fire alarms sprinkler system utilities and structural elements of the building shall be maintained and protected from the elements 3 there shall be no harborage of rodents and active infestation in the building 4 the interior of the building shall be free from any accumulation of rubbish or garbage 5 the building shall not be used for nuisance activities f maintenance and removal of signs 1 every sign box or structure shall be maintained in a safe presentable and sound structural condition 2 to prevent rust peeling flaking fading or rotting all sign boxes and supports shall be painted unless they have been anodized or similarly treated 3 broken panels missing letters defective illumination torn fabric flaking or peeling paint and other damage to a sign shall be replaced or repaired 4 the owner shall be responsible for the removal of unused signs a sign box may display a blank sign face until such unit is occupied 5 all ground signs shall be removed if a building is 100 percent vacant or the building is removed 6 any sign which presents an immediate danger to the public may be removed at the direction of the village manager or designee in accordance with the procedures set forth in this section 7 signs that have been approved by the appearance commission shall be maintained in accordance with the approved plan 8 submit the property for a certificate of compliance inspection for the vacancy at the request of
