 article xviii  massage services division 1  generally definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning approved massage school means a facility which meets the minimum standards for training and curriculum for the practice of massage and massage therapy and is accredited by one of the following 1 accrediting bureau of health education schools abhes  2 accrediting council for continuing education and training accet  3 accrediting commission for career schools and colleges of technology accsct  4 accrediting council of independent colleges and schools acics  5 council of occupational education coe  6 commission of massage training accreditation comta  7 distance education and training council detc  8 international massage somatic therapies accreditation council imstac  9 north central association of colleges and schools ncacas massage or massage therapy means a system of structured palpation or movement of the soft tissue of the body the system may include but is not limited to techniques such as effleurage or stroking and gliding petrissage or kneading tapotement or percussion friction vibration compression and stretching activities as they pertain to massage therapy these techniques may be applied by a licensed massage therapist with or without the aid of lubricants salt or herbal preparations hydromassage thermal massage or a massage device that mimics or enhances the actions possible by human hands the purpose of the practice of massage as permitted and licensed under this article is to enhance the general health and well being of the mind and body of the recipient massage does not include the diagnosis of a specific pathology massage does not include those acts of physical therapy or therapeutic or corrective measures that are outside the scope of massage therapy practice as defined in this article massage services establishment means any business establishment or location in the village having a source of income or compensation derived from the practice of massage or massage therapy as defined in this section or which has a place of business where any person firm association corporation or other entity engages in or carries on any of the activities described in the definition of massage or massage therapy massage services means the transaction or operation of any business or enterprise in the village that is organized and operated in whole or in part for the purpose of practicing performing providing or delivering a massage or massage therapy in return for compensation or consideration of any type massage therapist means any person who for any consideration whatsoever engages in the practice of massage or massage therapy as defined in this section   c3265  1 4192004 cross reference definitions generally  12 violations declared nuisance violations of this article are declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in the village manager may in addition to other remedies provided for in recommend that the corporation counsel seek injunctive relief or pursue other civil actions necessary to eradicate the nuisance c3265  1 4192004 sanitation and health regulations for massage services establishment licensees massage services establishment licensees must follow certain regulations in the operation of their massage services business to ensure a clean and sanitary environment such regulations include but are not limited to the following a all massage tables equipment and areas shall have surfaces that are readily disinfected b the establishment shall have adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing of nondisposable instruments and materials used such nondisposable instruments equipment and materials shall be disinfected after each use c clean linen towels and other materials shall be stored in a manner so as to be protected from contamination all soiled linens towels and other materials shall be kept in a covered container and stored separately d an adequate supply of clean linens and towels shall be made available linens and towels must be for individual customer use and laundered after each use e all areas in a massage therapy establishment shall be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary manner f all creams oils lotions etc shall be kept in clean closed containers and shall be dispensed in doses so that the bulk containers are not contaminated between customers g no massage treatment shall be administered to a patron exhibiting any skin fungus skin infection skin inflammation or skin eruption unless a licensed physician certifies in writing that such patron may be safely massaged h the establishment must be equipped with a hand sink with dispensed soap and towels the therapist shall wash hands in hot running water with soap before treating each patron c3025 942001  c3265  1 4192004 have surfaces that are readily disinfected 2 nondisposable instruments equipment and materials shall be disinfected after each use 3 an adequate supply of clean linens and towels shall be made newsrack shall be assessed an impound fee the impound fee shall be determined by the village manager and be based on the actual cost to the village for removal and storage including a 10 percent person responsible for installing the newsrack shall be entitled to possession of the newsrack removed in accordance with this section d unclaimed newsracks should a permittee or the person generally definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning charitable organization means an organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an indefinite number of the public educational organization means an organization or institution organized and operated to provide systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by methods common to schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope and intensity with the course of study presented in taxsupported schools fraternal organization means an organization of persons including but not limited to ethnic organizations having a common interest organized and operated exclusively to promote the welfare of its members and to benefit the general public on a continuing and consistent basis labor organization means an organization composed of workers organized with the objective of betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit and the development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations net proceeds means the gross receipts from the conduct of raffles less reasonable sums expended for prizes local license fees and other reasonable operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle nonprofit organization means an organization or institution organized and conducted on a notforprofit basis with no personal profit inuring to anyone as a result of the operation raffle means a form of lottery as defined in 720 ilcs 5282 conducted by an organization licensed under this article in which 1 the player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by some other medium 1 or more of which chances is to be designated the winning chance 2 the winning chance is to be determined drawing or by some other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part of persons conducting or connected with the lottery except that the winning chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting contest religious organization means any church congregation society or organization founded for the purpose of religious worship veterans organization means an organization or association composed of members of which substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses widows or widowers of veterans the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to confer a public benefit  cross reference definitions generally  12 conduct of raffles  use of proceeds licenses issued under this article are subject to the following restrictions 1 the entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game 2 no person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may participate in the management or operation of the raffle 3 no person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in the management or operation of the raffle 4 a licensee may rent premises on which to determine the winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under this article 5 raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on the license and winning chances may be determined only at those locations specified on the licenses 6 no person under the age of 18 years may participate in the conducting of raffles or chances a person under the age of 18 years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when accompanied by such persons parent or guardian 7 the aggregate retail value of all prizes and merchandise awarded by a licensee in a single raffle should not exceed $20000000 8 the maximum retail value of each prize awarded in a single raffle should not exceed $20000000 9 the maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance issued or sold shall not exceed $20000 10 the maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or sold shall not exceed 180 days  raffles manager all operation of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a single raffles manager designated by the organization the manager shall give a fidelity bond in a sum to be determined by the village manager or designee for each application in favor of the organization conditioned upon the managers honesty in the performing of the managers duties terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the licensing authority not less than 30 days prior to its cancellation the village may waive this bond requirement by including a waiver provision in the license issued to an organization under this article  provided that a license containing such waiver provision shall be granted only by unanimous vote of the members of the licensed organization  records a each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep the records of its gross receipts expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined all deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount and the description of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee purpose amount and date of payment b gross receipts from the operation of raffles programs shall be segregated from other revenues of the organization including bingo gross receipts if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization pursuant to license therefor issued by the state department of revenue and placed in a separate account each organization shall have a separate record of its raffles the person who accounts for gross receipts expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of the organization c each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report monthly to terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning transient merchant means any person whether as owner agent consignee or employee whether a resident of the village or not who engages in a temporary business for any period of time less than 12 months of buying or selling at wholesale or retail and delivering to any person goods wares and merchandise within the village and who for the purpose of conducting such business occupies or uses any parcel of land building tent room apartment shop store structure or other place within the village for the purpose of exhibition and sale or offering to purchase or sell such goods wares and merchandise either privately publicly or at public auction this definition shall not apply to 1 the transportation of goods wares and merchandise and chattels of every description which are merely being transported or which were raised produced or manufactured by the person transporting the goods wares merchandise or chattels 2 persons selling vegetables fruits or perishable farm products at booths on or adjacent to the property owned or occupied by them 3 any persons who while occupying a temporary location do not sell from stock but exhibit samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only 4 persons using motor vehicles for the transportation of goods wares and merchandise for delivery to an established list of customers or clientele or to or from an established place of business 5 persons conducting judicial or other sales under legal proceedings 6 persons selling at circuses carnivals or other public events provided they are otherwise licensed by the village  cross reference definitions stations at exits in buildings over three stories 4 notification devices in each unit that sound upon activation of the sprinkler system 5 exit signsemergency lighting with battery back up in all common areas including hallways stairways storage rooms and basements 6 buildings greater than 3 stories shall have manual pull stations at each exit and a stand pipe in the stairwell c conversion of footnotes  2  cross reference fee for automatic dialing devices connected to police department  4635  permit fees for alarm systems and users false alarm fees  4674 state law reference private detective private alarm private security and locksmith act 225 ilcs 4461 et seq division 1  generally definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning alarm contractor means a person or company licensed by the state of illinois to engage in the activity of altering installing leasing maintaining moving repairing replacing selling servicing or responding to an emergency alarm system alarm occurrence means the activation of an alarm system for or as a result of any reason whatsoever which notifies either the police andor the fire departments to respond to the premises on which the alarm system exists alarm detection system means any assemblage of mechanical or electrical equipment or devices or a single device such as a solid state unit which plugs directly into a 110volt ac line arranged to signal the presence of a hazard a fire an occurrence of an unauthorized intrusion or other activity requiring urgent and immediate attention the term alarm detection system shall include the terms automatic holdup alarm system burglar alarm system fire alarm system and holdup alarm system the following alarm systems are specifically excluded from the provisions of this article medical emergency alarms motor vehicle alarm systems alarm systems used solely to alert or signal persons within the premises and alarm systems which monitor temperature humidity or other conditions not directly related to a fire incident or the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into the premises or an attempted robbery or burglary at the premises alarm monitoring system means a system in which the operation of electrical protection circuits and devices are signaled automatically to recorded in and maintained alarm user means a person firm entity partnership association corporation company organization or state or political subdivision thereof in possession or control of any building structure facility or property in the village wherein an alarm system is installed and maintained alarm user permit means a permit issued by the village for the privilege and ability to operate an alarm system within the village combined communication center also known as ccc means the location at which alarm monitoring system signals are received false alarm means any alarm occurrence except when the following circumstances exist 1 evidence of an actual intrusion or an obvious intrusion attempt 2 evidence of an actual fire or other smoke noxious gas or high temperatures on premises 3 evidence of electrical utility outage conditions affecting a general neighborhood area 4 evidence of violent and extreme conditions of nature or acts of god including thunder snow ice and electrical storms 5 alarm occurrences during the 30day period following installation of an alarm system at an address that did not previously have an alarm system holdup alarm system means an alarm system signaling a robbery or attempted robbery fire alarm system means a system or portion of a combination system that consists of components and circuits arranged to monitor and annunciate the status of fire alarm or supervisory signalinitiating devices and to initiate the appropriate response to those signals village alarm administrator shall also be known as the communications coordinator whose responsibilities include coordination administration and documentation of alarm and detection systems users in the village 01  c3306  1 1042004 1 4202011  c4167  3 832015 editors note see editors note following  3833 secs 38413860  reserved division 2  alarm user permit required it shall be unlawful for any person entity or alarm user to maintain or operate an alarm system without a valid and effective alarm user permit 02  c3306  1 1042004 application applications for alarm user permits shall be made to the village manager or designee on forms prescribed and furnished by the village manager or designee the village manager or designee may request additional information from the applicant 01  c3306  1 1042004 revocation of permit a the village manager shall have the authority to revoke all permits issued under this division in addition to the provisions contained in this article the village manager shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations for the conduct of a hearing relating to the revocation of a permit b the village manager is hereby given the authority to revoke the permit if the village manager finds 1 the permittee has not complied with applicable codes ordinances statutes laws policies or rules and regulations 2 the permittee has made fraudulent false or misrepresentative statements in the application for the permit 3 the permittee owes the village required fees or outstanding fines or penalties 4 more than 10 false alarms for 1 alarm system have occurred in any calendar year c notice and hearing the village manager or designee may revoke suspend or take other action with respect to a permit in accordance with the following procedures 1 the village manager or designee shall send written notice of the intent to revoke or suspend a permit by certified mail or personal delivery setting forth the reasons for revocation or suspension 2 the notice shall state that the effective date of the revocation or suspension shall be 30 days from the date of the notice shall state the effective date and shall inform the permit holder of the right to submit in writing within 15 days of the date of the notice either a documentation to explain the past occurrences stated in the notice and to propose corrective action to eliminate the violations  or b a request for hearing 3 if the village manager or designee accepts the corrective action proposed by the permit holder the manager or designee shall respond in writing stating the conditions for continuing to hold the permit and retracting or deferring the notice of intent to revoke or suspend the permit 4 if the permit holder requests a hearing the village manager or designee shall hold a hearing within 30 days of the date of the original notice at which hearing the permit holder and a police department representative or fire department representative other than the designee of the village manager conducting the hearing shall have the right to present any evidence and cross examine witnesses 5 the village manager or designee conducting the hearing shall render a written decision within 7 days of the hearing sent to the permit holder by certified mail or personal delivery either a revoking or suspending the permit stating the effective date of the action  or b stating any conditions for continuing to hold the permit 07  c3306  1 1042004 reinstatement of revoked or suspended permit any alarm user whose permit has been revoked or suspended pursuant to this article may request hereinafter the responsible party to create encourage permit or allow a public nuisance to occur on the property owned managed controlled or occupied by them for purposes of the section a person shall have the same meaning as of the responsible party may be subject to the following procedures 1 the village manager shall appoint a fiveperson committee comprised of one appointee from each of the following community development department police department health department human services division and the managers office the committee shall be known as the nuisance intervention and prevention nip committee the nip committee may consult with other village personnel as needed 2 whenever any information is made available to a village employee indicating that a property may constitute a public nuisance based upon activities or omissions described in clauses 20 21 and 22 of subsection d above then that employee shall refer the matter to the nip committee the nip committee shall convene and review all facts and information in relation to the referral if the nip committee reasonably believes that the activity constitutes a public nuisance it may authorize and initiate any actions permitted by the state law 3 in addition to taking any other action the nip committee may initiate a nuisance avoidance meeting with the responsible party the nip committee shall establish a nuisance avoidance meeting with the responsible party by giving them any type of notice that is reasonable based upon the circumstances including but not limited to written notice via first class mail or telephonic or personal notice if the circumstances require expedient action 4 the purpose of the nuisance avoidance meeting between the nip committee and the responsible party is to discuss the facts and information and allow the responsible party to provide additional information it is a violation of the a responsible party to fail to appear at a nuisance avoidance meeting the nip committee may decide to require the responsible party to take reasonable and warranted actions to correct or prevent the activity or omission that is a violation of the decision shall be provided in writing it is a violation of the a responsible party not to implement the corrective or preventative actions 5 the corrective or preventative actions may require the responsible party to take such actions reasonably calculated to correct or prevent the occurrence of a public nuisance in ordering such actions the nip committee shall consider the magnitude of the harm caused by the activities or omissions the value of the property the impact on residents property owners and businesses in the area or village and other relevant circumstances such actions may include but are not limited to a making improvements to the premises requested by the village b installing alarms lighting or other measures to enhance security c hiring of licensed and insured security personnel d hiring a thirdparty to take the corrective or preventative actions e the initiation and execution of eviction proceedings against certain tenants f correction of a 6 the nip committee may recommend that the village initiate the filing of a cause of action in the circuit court or a violation citation for administrative adjudication nothing in this preclude the village from initiating a cause of action in circuit court or issuing a violation notice for administrative adjudication without action or recommendation by the nip committee 7 each day that a violation of this shall be a separate and distinct violation the village may enforce this its administrative adjudication program to the extent permitted by law or action initiated in a court of competent jurisdiction the village manager is authorized to conduct hearings to determine whether any license permit or certificate of occupancy held by the responsible party or issued in connection within any property should be revoked or suspended 8 no person public nuisance b removal required it shall be unlawful for any owner of any lot or land in the village to permit or maintain on any such lot or land any elm tree dead elm wood or diseased or infested tree which is declared a public nuisance by this section and it shall be the duty of any such owner promptly to remove and properly dispose of any such tree or dead wood under the supervision and enforcement thereof the village manager or designee or duly authorized representative is hereby authorized and empowered to enter upon any lot or land in the village at any reasonable hour for the purpose of inspecting any diseased or infested trees or dead wood situated thereon and may remove such specimens from any such tree as are required for the purpose of laboratory analysis or to determine whether such tree is diseased or infested it shall be unlawful for any person to take any action to prevent the village manager or designee or duly authorized representative from entering on any lot or land in the village for the purpose of such inspection or to interfere with the village manager or designee or such representative in the performance of any of the duties provided for in this section d notice to abate  abatement by village 1 if on laboratory analysis of specimens removed from any tree by the village manager or designee it is determined that such tree is a public nuisance as provided in this section or if the village manager or designee determines that any dead or substantially dead tree or dead wood is a public nuisance the village manager or designee shall serve or cause to be served upon the person firm or corporation that is owner of the lot or land on which such tree or dead wood is located a written notice requiring such owner to comply with the provisions of this section if the person upon whom such notice is served fails neglects or refuses to remove and destroy in a proper manner such tree or dead wood within 10 days after service of such notice the village manager or designee or duly authorized representative may proceed to remove and dispose of such tree or dead wood in a proper manner and assess the cost thereof against the owner of such lot or land and the amount of such cost shall be paid by such owner to the village 2 service of notice provided for in this subsection shall be by mail or personal service if the owner is a resident of the village if such owner cannot be found in the village or is a nonresident written notice shall be served by registered mail addressed to the owner at the owners last known address and by publication at least 1 time in a newspaper of general circulation in the village e costs of abatement by village additional to penalties if the village removes from any lot or land in the village any infected tree which is a public nuisance or any dead or substantially dead tree or dead wood which is a public nuisance the costs of the work done by the village assessed against the owner of the volunteer growth not cultivated or useful for human food or enjoyment and which when in blossom exhales an unpleasant or noxious odor or gives off pollen irritating to human tissue  and also any high or bank vegetable growth that may conceal debris or filthy deposits or constitute a fire hazard when dry the term weeds shall include grass which is permitted to attain a growth of more than 6 inches b declaration of nuisance any weeds are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any person owning or in control of any plot of ground to permit the growth of weeds thereon all persons owning or in control of property located within the village shall keep their front and rear yards the parkway in front of or adjacent to their premises and property adjacent to public rightsofway in alleys free from weeds c notice of violation  abatement by village if an owner or one in control of a plot of ground violates any part of this section the village manager or designee shall send by certified mail personal service or posting notice on the subject property a notice of such violation to such person informing the person of the violation and requesting that such violation be abated within 5 days from the time of mailing posting or serving the notice if the violation is not abated within the 5day period the village agent shall enter upon the property where the weeds are growing and shall proceed to destroy the weeds thereon causing the violation and any expense incurred by the village in so doing shall be a charge against the owner or person in control so failing and such charge may be recovered in an appropriate action in law instituted by the corporation counsel in addition thereto the village may create a lien against the property involved d lien for costs incurred by village 1 any costs incurred by the village or its duly appointed officers or agents in removing weeds from any property shall be a lien upon the real estate so affected and the lien shall be superior to all other liens and encumbrances except tax liens provided that within 60 days after such cost and expense is incurred the village or person performing the service by authority of the village in its or such persons own name files notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds the notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out i a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof ii the amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred or payable for the service and iii the date or dates when such costs and expenses were incurred by the village or one acting under its direction and authority however the lien shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to the weed cutting and prior to the filing of such notice and the lien shall not be valid as to any mortgagee judgment creditor or other lienor whose rights in and to the affected real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice upon payment of the costs and expenses by the owner of or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien 2 the cost of the cutting of weeds shall not be a lien on the real estate affected unless a notice is personally served on or sent by certified mail to the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the preceding owners and tenants to commit to crime free tenancies a the definitions contained in of the skokie village be incorporated by reference to this shall apply as fully set forth b any owner that leases property to another person shall utilize a crime free lease addendum the addendum is to make the occupancy of a leased premises by an individual engaged in violent or drugrelated crimes or the use of a leased premises in the commission of a crime or in furtherance of the commission of certain criminal activity by a tenant a tenants invitee or other person authorized or allowed by the tenant or the tenants family to be on the leased premises a lease violation the language for a crime free lease addendum is in subsection h below c in the event that criminal activity occurs in a leased premises that constitutes i any class of felony or ii a class a misdemeanor at least twice in one year then an owner or authorized agent shall initiate eviction proceedings against the tenant participating in the criminal activity as specified in the illinois civil procedure 735 ilcs 59101 et seq for the purposes of this a tenant that was a nonculpable victim or was not participating in criminal activity shall not be evicted for the reason of the criminal activity this also not apply to victims of domestic violence dating violence sexual assault or stalking for any violation of the crime free lease addendum in the event the owner authorized agent or tenant believes that the circumstances are such that eviction should not be undertaken then they shall file a written request detailing the circumstances with the nuisance intervention and prevention committee hereinafter nip committee and request a determination of whether eviction is inappropriate the nip committee may at its discretion meet with the owner authorized agent and any other person including the tenant that may have relevant information regarding the circumstances the nip committee shall render a written determination on the question of whether eviction is inappropriate and may deliver it via first class mail the nip committee may consider but is not limited to the following factors 1 the activity itself 2 the age of the participants involved in the activity 3 whether the tenant was a nonculpable victim of the activity or 4 any other factors the nip committee deems relevant d when the provisions of paragraph c require the owner to initiate eviction proceedings the owner or authorized agent shall initiate action to evict a tenant within fifteen 15 days of the date i the owner or authorized agent becomes aware or should have become aware that criminal activity warranting eviction took place or ii that a written determination is delivered to the owner by the nip committee pursuant to paragraph c an owner may include language in the lease that authorizes eviction for more minor offenses than indicated in paragraph h in the event criminal activity occurs that is not a felony or a class a misdemeanor twice within twelve months then the decision to initiate eviction proceedings is discretionary for the owner e whenever an owner is proceeding with an eviction pursuant to paragraph h the owner may request that the village of skokie corporation counsel or designee appear before the court or prepare a written submission when there is a hearing on the eviction not to represent the owner but to support the eviction proceeding pursuant to the terms of this decision to appear is at the discretion of the corporation counsel f it is a violation of the an owner to not include a crime free lease addendum in a written lease affecting property in the village if the leasing of a property is an oral arrangement then the owner must notify the tenant in writing that the crime free lease addendum is a condition of the lease and the tenant is obligated to adhere to its language the owner or authorized agent must keep sufficient records to demonstrate that such notice is provided it is a violation of the an owner to not enforce the crime free lease addendum g the village may conduct crime free property seminars from time to time any owner agent of an owner or tenant may be required to attend the villages crime free property seminars at the request of the village manager based on the following considerations 1 if the property rented or leased by the owner is a nuisance property not be construed to exclude other noises coming within the definition of this article 1 building or construction operations the use of any pile driver shovel hammer derrick hoist tractor roller or other mechanical apparatus operated by fuel or electric power in building or construction operations other than between the hours of  am and  pm on weekdays and saturdays except in case of urgent sound originates shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section however the utilization of lawn care or construction equipment or the sounding of horns or whistles on locomotives as shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning proper disposal of underground tanks if a tank is to be disposed of as junk it shall be retested for flammable vapors and if necessary rendered gasfree so that vapors from the combustible or flammable liquid from the tank are not present in a concentration sufficient to support combustion after junking and before releasing to a junk dealer a sufficient number of holes or openings at least 2 percent of the total surface area of the tank should be made in it to render it unfit for further use nfpa 327 standard procedures for cleaning or safeguarding small tanks and containers provides information on safe procedures for such operation proper removal of an underground tank means that 1 all flammable or combustible liquids from the tank and from connecting lines are removed 2 piping is disconnected at all tank openings 3 connecting lines which are not to be used further are removed and all tank openings are capped or plugged 4 tanks are removed from the ground 5 after removal the tank shall be gasfree so that vapors from the combustible or flammable liquid from the tank are not present in a concentration sufficient to support combustion on the premises as required by nfpa 327 or the tank may be transported to an area not accessible to the public and the gasfreeing completed at that location 6 adherence to the regulations of the office of the state fire marshal title 41 act 152 regulation of tanks as well as any other applicable state and federal regulations is required properly safeguarding an underground tank means that 1 all products are removed 2 the tank is filled with a solution of water and inerting chemicals to reduce the oxygen content in the enclosed space to a concentration at which combustion cannot take place 3 all fill gauge suction or other lines except vents are capped 4 adherence to the regulations of the office of the state fire marshal title 41 act 152 regulation of tanks as well as any other applicable state and federal regulations is required underground tanks means underground storage tanks which are used for the storage of motor fuel or other combustible or flammable liquids b declaration of nuisance 1 any underground tanks which are out of service for 180 days and have not been properly safeguarded are considered dangerous and unsafe and are hereby declared a public nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any property owner to permit such tanks thereon 2 any outofservice underground storage tanks which were previously filled with an inert solid material shall be removed as part of any new construction or substantial remodeling c notice of violation  abatement by village if a property owner violates any part of this section the fire chief or the fire chiefs agent shall send by certified mail a notice of such violation to such person informing the person of the violation and that such violation must be abated within 10 days from the time of mailing the notice if the violation is not abated within the 10day period the village agent shall enter upon the property where the underground tanks are located and shall proceed to properly safeguard the underground tanks with an inert solid material any expense incurred by the village in safeguarding the tanks shall be a charge against the property owner and such charge may be recovered in an appropriate action in law instituted by the corporation counsel in addition thereto the village may create a lien against the property involved d lien for costs of abatement by village any costs incurred by the village or its duly appointed officers or agents in safeguarding underground tanks shall be a lien upon the real estate so affected and the lien shall be superior to all other liens and encumbrances except tax liens provided that within 60 days after such cost and expense is incurred the village or the person performing the service by authority of the village in its or such persons own name files notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds the notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out i a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof ii the amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred or payable for the service and iii the date or dates when such costs and expenses were incurred by the village or one acting under its direction and authority upon payment of the costs and expenses by the owner of or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record as in the case of filing materials a definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning hazardous materials means any substance or material in a quantity or form which in the determination of the fire chief or the fire chiefs authorized representative poses an unreasonable and imminent risk to the life health or safety of persons or property or to the ecological balance of the environment and shall include but not be limited to such substances as explosives radioactive materials petroleum or petroleum products or gases poisons etiologic biologic agents flammables or corrosives b cleanup and abatement authorized the village manager or designee is authorized to order the cleanup or abatement of the effects of any hazardous materials c liability for costs of cleanup or abatement any person or persons who intentionally or negligently cause such deposits shall be liable for the payment of all costs incurred as a result of such cleanup or abatement including but not limited to actual labor costs of village personnel including workers compensation benefits fringe benefits and administrative overhead costs of equipment operation and materials obtained directly by the village and other costs including attorneys fees incurred as a result of a contract by the village for labor material and removal however the authority to recover costs under this section shall not include costs of actual fire suppression services which are normally or usually provided by the fire department d lien for costs incurred by village 1 any costs incurred by the village or its duly appointed officers or agents in cleaning up or abating the effects of such deposits pursuant to this section shall be a lien upon the real estate so affected and the lien shall be superior to all other liens and encumbrances except tax liens provided that within 60 days after such cost and expense is incurred the village or person performing the service by authority of the village in its or such persons own name files notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds the notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out i a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof ii the amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred or payable for the service and iii the date or dates when such costs and expenses were incurred by the village or one acting under its direction and authority however the lien shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to such cleanup or abatement and prior to the filing of such notice and the lien shall not be valid as to any mortgagee judgment creditor or other lienor whose rights in and to the affected real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice upon payment of the costs and expenses by the owner of or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien 2 the cost of the cleanup and abatement shall not be a lien on the real estate affected unless a notice is personally served on or sent by certified mail to the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the preceding year the notice shall be delivered or sent after the cleanup or abatement of such deposits on the property the notice shall contain a copy of this section and 65 ilcs 511207 and shall identify the affected real estate by common description and the location of the hazardous materials e remedies additional to other remedies and penalties the remedy provided by this section shall be in addition to any other remedies or penalties provided by law 17 cross reference environment ch 42 federal law painted every 5 years with paint approved by and to the color scheme specified by the village manager or designee a licensed plumbing contractor bonded for work in the village shall obtain necessary purpose a there is hereby established a foreign fire insurance board of the village of skokie hereafter known as the ffi board to receive and expend foreign fire insurance tax funds hereafter known as tax funds for the maintenance use and benefit of the village of skokie fire department in accordance with the illinois compiled statutes all tax funds received by the village are public funds and shall be deposited in the general fund but shall be earmarked for the purposes stated herein and be assigned a separate account number the tax funds shall be subject to appropriation by the mayor and the board of trustees during the usual budget cycle and subject to the same procedures except as specified herein as all other village revenues and receipts c3663  1 222009 definition a members of the the department immediate action is required to protect the public from a dangerously contagious or infectious disease in the event of an immediate order issued without prior consent or court order the department shall as soon as practical within 48 hours after issuing the order obtain the consent of the person or owner or file a petition requesting a court order authorizing the isolation or dangerously contagious or infectious disease 2 all other reasonable means of correcting the problem have been exhausted and no less restrictive alternative exists for purposes of determining whether no less restrictive alternative exists the court shall consider evidence showing that quarantine or isolation is the measure provided for in a rule of the department or in guidelines issued by the centers for disease control and prevention or the world health organization c persons who are or are about to be ordered to be isolated or quarantined and owners of places that are or are about to be closed and made off limits to the public shall have the right to counsel d persons who are ordered to be isolated or quarantined or who are owners of places that are ordered to be closed and made off be made so that access to outdoor play areas shall be physically restricted via a temporary enclosure or permanent fence to safely protect children from traffic and other hazards 10 nonchildcare all court records referred to in the state department of children and family services licensing standards for day care homes shall be submitted to the department for consideration prior to licensing approval the department in conjunction with the village police department shall conduct an annual criminal record check of all day care home operators family members staff members new employees and volunteers and report their findings to the village manager if the village manager or designee finds that an individual should not be allowed in the day care home as an operatorowner family member employee or volunteer the village manager or designee shall notify the applicant of this fact 12 hours of operation  maximum time of care children served in a day care home shall not remain on the premises for more than 12 hours in a 24hour period the hours of operation for a day care home within the village will be between  am and  pm 13 screening of children for illness the caregiver shall conduct a daily preadmissions screening to determine if the child has obvious symptoms of illness if symptoms of illness are present the caregiver shall determine whether to provide care for the child depending upon the apparent degree of illness other children present and facilities available to provide care for the ill child whenever children are admitted into the day care home with a communicable illness or whenever a child develops a communicable illness while under the care of a day care home operator the caregiver shall immediately notify the department of all communicable illnesses present as required in the state rules and regulations for the control of communicable diseases 14 storage of medication all medication shall be stored in a locked cabinet or container the storage area shall be welllighted and inaccessible to children 15 record of incidents or accidents a complete written record will be maintained of any and all serious incidents or accidents involving a child or a group of children this record shall include the date and time of the incident or accident and the action taken concerning the incidentaccident these incidents or accidents include all situations requiring the emergency and nonemergency medical services of a physician a hospital the police department andor the fire department the village health department will be notified by telephone of all such incidents or accidents within 24 hours of their occurrence in addition a written copy of the record shall be sent to the health department within 7 days 16 handwashing supplies  drinking cups each child shall be provided with an individually labeled towel washcloth and drinking cup singleuse disposable articles are acceptable provisions shall also be made for providing liquid dispensed soap powdered soap or properly drained bar soap for appropriate handwashing by all children caregivers assistants and family members 17 appropriate and safe design required the materials and equipment and their arrangement and use must be appropriate to the development needs and of safe design for the children in care 18 cleaning of materials and toys materials and toys shall be cleaned and sanitized as needed with a germicidal solution materials and toys shall also be kept orderly attractive and accessible to children 19 smoking disclosure it shall be the duty and responsibility of the licensee to disclose to the parent or guardian of the child being cared for whether any caregiver or other individual in the home smokes during the hours of operation 20 construction requirements each building used as a family day care home must meet the requirements of the bocanational existing structures as adopted by the village cross reference existing structures code  22181 et seq 21 maximum occupancy the occupant load shall be a minimum of 100 square feet per occupant 22 exits a every room used for sleeping living or dining purposes shall have at least 2 means of egress at least 1 of which shall be a door or stairway providing a means of unobstructed travel to the outside of the building at street or ground level the second means of egress may be a window approved by the village manager or designee which can be opened from the inside by the caregiver or a member of the staff no room or space shall be occupied for living or sleeping purposes which is accessible only by a ladder by folding stairs or trap door b where clients are located on a floor basement below the level of exit discharge at least 1 means of egress shall be an exit discharging directly to the outside and the vertical travel to ground level shall not exceed 8 feet the second means of egress may be a window approved by the village manager or designee which can be opened from the inside by the caregiver or a member of the staff no facility shall be located more than 1 story below the ground c travel distance to exits shall be no greater than 150 feet d all exitways shall be lighted by normal sources 23 stairs every stairway shall comply with the minimum requirements for stairs which are 8inch risers 9inch treads and 32inch stair width all stairs shall be maintained free of items of storage 24 width of doors each exit door shall be a minimum of 32 inches wide 25 closet latches every closet door latch shall be such that children can open the door from inside the closet 26 bathroom doors every bathroom door lock shall be designed to permit the opening of the locked door from the outside in an emergency the opening device shall be readily accessible to the caregiver or a member of the staff 27 interior finishes the interior finish of all occupied spaces in the home shall be a minimum of class c 76200 flame spread rated the village manager or designee shall have the authority to approve interior finishes 28 electrical wiring electrical wiring shall meet the electrical code of the village as contained in the village manager or designee shall have the authority to classify footnotes  8  cross reference businesses ch 26  business license fees  4671 et seq  zoning ch 118 state law reference nursing home care act 210 ilcs 451101 et seq  longterm care peer review and quality assessment and assurance protection act 745 ilcs 551 et seq division 1  generally purpose of article it is the purpose of this article and the policy of the village to establish standards for the licensing and regulation of all intermediate care and skilled nursing care facilities within the village and to require compliance with at least the minimum requirements of the nursing home care act of 197 210 ilcs 451101 et seq including the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder 01 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning administrator means a person who is charged with the general administration and supervision of a facility and licensed under the nursing home administrators licensing and disciplinary act 225 ilcs 701 et seq applicant means any person making application for a license under this article department means the public health department of the village director means the director of the village public health department facility means longterm care facility fire chief means the fire chief of the village fire department longterm care facility 1 the term longterm care facility means a private home institution building residence or any other place whether operated for profit or not which provides personal care andor skilled nursing care on a 24hour basis for 3 or more persons who because of physical or mental incapacity may be unable to provide for their own needs and safety without the assistance of another person the term longterm care facility wherever used in this article shall include only skilled nursing facilities and intermediate care facilities those terms being defined as follows a intermediate care facility means a longterm care facility which provides basic nursing care and other restorative services under periodic medical direction such facilities are primarily for residents who have longterm illnesses or disabilities which may have reached a relatively stable plateau b skilled nursing facility means a longterm care facility which provides skilled nursing care continuous skilled nursing observations restorative nursing and other services under professional direction with frequent medical supervision such facilities are primarily provided for patients who need the type of care and treatment required during the postacute phase of illness or during reoccurrences of symptoms in longterm illness 2 this article does not apply to the following types of facilities a intermediate care facilities for the developmentally disabled as defined in the minimum standards for the licensing of longterm care facilities 198 210 ilcs 451101 et seq b community living facilities as defined in the minimum standards for community living facilities 198 210 ilcs 351 et seq manager means the village manager neglect means a failure of a facility to provide adequate medical or personal care or maintenance which failure may result in physical or mental injury to a resident or in the deterioration of a residents physical or mental condition nurse means a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse as defined in the nursing home care act 210 ilcs 451101 et seq owner means the individual partnership corporation association or other person who owns a facility if a facility is operated by a person who leases the physical plant which is owned by another person the term owner means the person who operates the facility except that if the person who owns the physical plant is an affiliate of the person who operates the facility and has significant control over the daytoday operations of the facility the person who owns the physical plant shall incur jointly and severally with the owner all liabilities imposed on an owner under this article personal care means assistance with meals dressing movement bathing or other personal needs or maintenance or general supervision and oversight of the physical and mental wellbeing of an individual who is incapable of maintaining a private independent residence or who is incapable of managing their person whether or not a guardian has been appointed for such individual 04 cross reference definitions generally  12 violations declared nuisance the operation or maintenance of a longterm care facility in violation of this article is declared a public nuisance as that term is defined in the manager may request in addition to other remedies provided in that the corporation counsel bring action for an injunction to enjoin the future operation or maintenance of any such longterm care facility 09 adoption of state regulations a the village hereby adopts by reference the minimum standards rules and regulations for the licensing of longterm care facilities prescribed and published by the state department of public health pursuant to the nursing home care act of 197 210 ilcs 451101 et seq and all rules regulations and amendments thereto a violation of any of such standards rules and regulations as adopted by this article shall be considered a violation of the provisions of this article b any reference in the minimum standards rules and regulations adopted by reference in this section to the department shall read as meaning the department of public health of the village c any reference in the minimum standards rules and regulations adopted by reference in this section to the director shall mean the director of the department of public health of the village d one copy of the minimum standards rules and regulations adopted by reference in this section shall be filed in the office of the village clerk and kept available for public use inspection and examination e at least 1 copy of the minimum standards rules and regulations adopted by reference in this section shall be kept on file in the department of public health of the village for public inspection 02 administration and enforcement the village manager or designee shall administer this article and may promulgate rules and regulations to carry out its enforcement 03 cross reference administration ch 2 inspections inspections of all longterm care facilities shall be made at least once every 60 days by a department nurse and by a sanitarian either separately or concurrently these inspections shall be conducted without prior notice to the longterm care facility 07 standards for operation and premises a resident assessment and security 1 within 5 days prior to or 72 hours after admittance to a longterm care facility each resident shall be examined by a licensed physician if after examination of the resident and review of the residents case history the physician determines that 1 or more of the following conditions are present the resident shall be referred to a certified psychiatrist or senior resident under the direction of a certified psychiatrist or a registered clinical psychologist for further evaluation a suffering from a mental deficiency diagnosed as moderate or mild or whose disability is attributable to mental retardation autism or other pathological conditions which generally originate before such individuals attain age 18 and which continue or can be expected to continue indefinitely and which constitute a substantial functioning handicap b suffering from mental illness diagnosed as psychosis or psychoneurosis which requires medical surgical or psychiatric management excluding individuals suffering from senile dementia c a history of aggressive hostile or homicidal behavior or a history of suicide attempts d a history of or suffering from mental andor physical illness or disorder related to or caused by chronic alcoholism or addiction to drugs 2 upon completion of the examination the physician shall fill out the resident assessment form provided by the village which shall become a part of the residents permanent record the form shall contain a diagnosis as well as any restrictions to be placed on the residents movement andor activities 3 all residents must use 1 entryexit point in each facility except for emergencies the entryexit point must be monitored 24 hours each day by a staff member the staff member must sign each resident in and out of the facility and must document the following information a residents name b time of exiting the facility c destination d estimated time of return e actual time of return and who the resident was accompanied by 4 it is the responsibility of the staff to determine that any resident leaving the facility is in compliance with physicians orders if an alarm is present and activated at the entryexit point a staff person is not required at the entryexit point between the hours of  pm and  am b review of resident care each longterm care facility shall establish a procedure for review of resident care based on the evaluation of a residents immediate and longterm needs such review shall occur once every 6 months or more frequently as needed this procedure shall be the responsibility of a care review committee consisting of at least 1 supervisory nurse 1 nurses aide 1 social worker and 1 activity worker the residents physician andor psychiatrist shall also be included in the absence of the residents physician a signed statement stating approval of the residents care plan shall be included in the care review proceedings other persons shall be included where appropriate the resident when able shall be encouraged to participate in the care review committee or if not able may be represented by a person of the residents own choosing c nursing care the following personnel requirements shall apply in addition to the state personnel requirements under the nursing home care act of 197 210 ilcs 451101 et seq 1 in longterm care facilities there shall be a fulltime director of nurses licensed as a registered nurse in the state the director of nurses shall be on duty a minimum of 40 hours per week 2 in facilities of 100 beds or more there shall be an assistant director of nurses who shall be licensed as a registered nurse in the state either the assistant director or a supervising nurse who shall also be a registered nurse and licensed in the state shall be on duty on those days on which the director of nurses is not on duty the assistant director of supervising nurses shall not be included in the staffresident ratio calculations 3 in addition to the director of nurses and the assistant director of nurses there shall be at least 1 registered nurse or licensed practical nurse in charge of each 8hour shift who understands and speaks adequate english regardless of the size of the longterm care facility 4 within 6 months of  and annually thereafter each facility shall provide the nursing staff with a minimum of 18 continuing education units ceus of formal restorative nursing training approved by the department nurses receiving the training shall provide inservice training to all other nursing personnel 5 medication shall not be given to any patient without the written order of the attending physician all such medication shall be administered to the patient only by a physician registered nurse or licensed practical nurse who has successfully completed training in pharmacology and passed an examination approved by the illinois department of public health d required services 1 all longterm care facilities shall provide the following services a food service every longterm care facility shall comply with of this chapter b social services every longterm care facility shall provide 1 referral to appropriate agencies where there are indicators that financial psychiatric rehabilitative legal or social service help will be needed that the longterm care facility cannot provide 2 assistance with the residents adjustment to the longterm care facility and availability of continuing social services to residents of the facility including the availability of contact with family members to keep them involved 3 assistance to staff and residents in discharge planning and its implementation 4 assistance in providing inservice training to longterm care facility staff directed toward understanding emotional problems and social problems of residents and assistance in solving these problems 5 assistance to staff and residents in using community resources c mental health services all longterm care facilities with residents who have been discharged from psychiatric care within the last 3 years or with residents evidencing mental retardation or mental problems as determined by the residents attending physician andor psychiatrist shall meet the following staff requirements 1 a psychiatrist licensed to practice in the state shall be under formal contract by the facility to provide psychiatric treatment as deemed necessary by the attending physician andor the care review committee 2 social work shall be provided to individual residents defined in this subsection at the minimum rate of 30 minutes per week by a social worker who has either a masters in social work or a bachelors degree from an undergraduate program accredited by the council on social work education d activity program all longterm care facilities shall have an activity program directed by a fulltime staff member who shall be qualified by training or experience to direct an activity program records of programming and patient participation shall be maintained and shall include program goals attendance records and progress notes the plan for activity programming shall incorporate community resources and shall include group activities to promote learning about interpersonal behavior e physical therapy each longterm care facility shall make available to its residents the services of a registered physical therapist currently licensed by the state and under formal contract to the longterm care facility who shall under physicians orders spend such time within the facility as such orders may require f occupational therapyrecreational therapy all longterm care facilities shall make available the services of an occupational therapist who is registered by the american occupational therapy association or a therapeutic recreation specialist who shall be under formal contract to or employed fulltime by the longterm care facility 2 the determination as to which resident shall be taking part in any or all of the therapy programs provided for in subsection d1 of this section shall be made by the care review committee in consultation with the residents physician andor psychiatrist and therapists each of whom shall a complete an evaluation of each resident within 30 days of admission to the facility the evaluation shall include an assessment of communication skills mobility and physical strength and coordination and shall include recommendations for care and treatment needed to maintain or restore maximum functioning in such areas the evaluation shall be utilized by the care review committee in the review of resident care required in subsection b of this section b conduct bimonthly inservice programs designed to assist staff in carrying out restorative procedures c consult with the activity director as needed to plan activities which are supportive of restorative care needs e records all longterm care facilities shall maintain the following records 1 admission records a medical history and interim psychosocial history of each resident shall be compiled within 72 hours of admission to a longterm care facility and filed with each residents chart 2 active records a complete medical file including both past medical history and current medical status shall be maintained for each resident f additional standards the following standards shall apply in addition to state standards for all longterm care facilities hereafter constructed or for existing structures which are hereafter converted to use as intermediate care or skilled nursing care facilities and for all additions to existing facilities the rate for air changes per hour shall be certified by a licensed hvac contractor or a mechanical engineer at the longterm care facilitys expense 1 all corridors shall be provided with 6 tempered fresh air changes per hour at a rate of 2 cubic feet per minute per square foot 2 residents living space shall meet the following standards a there shall be 225 square feet of floor area per bed provided this 225 square feet of living space shall include no less than 120 square feet of bed space per single bedroom 100 square feet of bed space per multiple bedroom and 75 square feet of recreational and dining space per resident b all longterm care facilities shall provide each resident with a functional closet or wardrobe with a floor area of no less than 4 square feet this area is in addition to the requirements of subsection f3a of this section 3 there shall be 1 lavatory and 1 toilet for each bedroom except when there are no more than 4 residents in 2 rooms which have such facilities directly accessible from each of the 2 rooms 1 lavatory and toilet facility may be provided 4 there shall be 1 bathtub or shower for each 10 resident beds on each floor with direct access from the residents room or common hallway where this results in more than 3 tubs or showers they are to be placed in 2 separate rooms each such room shall contain a lavatory each residents privacy shall be preserved 5 pest control shall be provided by a certified pest control operator 6 all door alarms shall be the tamperpilferproof type door alarms shall either require a control key to deactivate the alarm or a remote switch which cannot be easily reached from outside the building or functional area to deactivate the alarm 06 emergency medical care and transportation it shall be the responsibility of each longterm care facility to provide or to have available emergency medical care including transportation for its residents if the longterm care facility fails to provide such care andor transportation and as a result the village is requested to respond there shall be a charge to the facility in accordance with which shall be borne exclusively by said facility for any of the following 1 transportation to a hospital for any treatment which can be handled by basic life support ambulance 2 transportation to a hospital of naturally deceased residents for the purpose of verifying death 3 inhouse treatment of residents not requiring advanced life support the village manager or designee shall have the authority to waive such charges upon ascertainment that the request for aid from the village was due to unforeseen often as may be necessary to determine adulteration or misbranding the village manager or designee may upon written notice to the owner or person in charge place a hold order on any food believed to be unwholesome or otherwise adulterated or misbranded under a hold order food shall be permitted to be suitably stored until a final determination is made on the disposition of the food it shall be unlawful for any person to remove or alter a hold order notice or tag placed on food by the village if a hearing is requested as provided for in this article such food or the containers thereof shall not be relabeled repacked reprocessed altered disposed of or destroyed without permission of the village manager or designee b equipment where equipment used in the preparation of food products is found to be in a state of disrepair unsafe unsuitable for use or unsanitary the owner or operator of such equipment shall be so notified by the village manager or designee such equipment may not be put back into service until written permission is obtained from the village manager or designee equipment which requires upgrading due to its condition will be assigned an amortization date upon completion of the amortization period the food permit holder shall replace or remove the piece of equipment the amortization period shall be determined by the current condition of the existing equipment factoring the equipments potential to contribute to a foodborne illness outbreak and the cost of the replacement piece of equipment this period shall not be more than 5 years the village manager or designee shall place a tag on the equipment with the tag specifying the date by which the equipment must be modified repaired or removed from the establishment it shall be unlawful for any person to remove or alter the tag placed on equipment by the village manager or designee such equipment shall not be altered without permission of the village manager or designee c hearing the owner
